Aunque el comportamiento de los agentes privados comien­ za a corroborar la hipótesis de cambio cíclico, no faltan voces que, señalando la debilidad de la recuperación, y enfatizando la gravedad de nuestros desequilibrios macroeconómicos, conclu­ yen que la recuperación es una «realidad virtual» que acabará por quebrarse en mil pedazos en el corto e inmediato futuro. En mi opinión, la economía española está irremediablemente abocada a crecer en 1995 a tasas que oscilan entre el 2,5 por ciento y el 3,5 por ciento, con una apreciable creación de em­ pleo ­en torno al 1,5 por ciento­ y un sector exterior en una có­ moda posición. Pero hay problemas: con una tasa de inflación en torno al 4,5 por ciento y un déficit público en el 6 por ciento del PIB resulta muy complicado intelectualmente defender la sostenibilidad indefinida del proceso de expansión. Si ambos de­ sequilibrios no se corrigen con presteza, más pronto que tarde acabarán por forzar un endurecimiento de las restantes políticas de demanda ­en especial de la política monetaria­ que inevita­ blemente ralentizará el ritmo de crecimiento de la economía es­ pañola. Para evitar ese escenario desolador las únicas vías son la profundización de las reformas estructurales, la restauranción de la credibilidad de la política presupuestaria, y el afianzamiento de la reputación del Banco de España como garante de la estabi­ lidad de precios. Las razones para mi optimismo son cuatro. En primer lugar, la recuperación registrada a lo largo de 1994 ha sido mucho más intensa de lo que la mayoría de los analistas esperaba al iniciarse el año. De hecho, y pese a que la recesión de 1992 y 1993 ha sido la peor de las últimas tres déca­ das, en el segundo trimestre del presente ejercicio la economía española había recuperado el nivel de Producto Interior Bruto que se registraba antes de iniciarse el período contractivo. Haber cerrado en la vertiente de la producción las secuelas de la rece­ sión en tan sólo cuatro trimestres no es, sin duda, una señal de debilidad, sino más bien todo lo contrario. Es más, el espectacu­ lar cambio que se ha producido en la composición de la deman­ da agregada del país y el hecho de que ahora se produzca lo mis­ mo que en junio de 1992, pero con menos empleo, pone de ma­ nifiesto los efectos inmediatos del intenso proceso de reestructu­ ración y racionalización acometido por nuestro tejido productivo en los trimestres de recesión: la economía española es una eco­ nomía más abierta que hace dos años ­el peso de las exportacio­ nes sobre el PIB ha pasado de 21,6 por ciento a 27,2 por ciento, mientras que las importaciones permanecían virtualmente estan­ cadas­ y, simultáneamente, es una economía más productiva y eficiente. Exactamente, un 6 por ciento más eficiente. La segunda razón para el optimismo es que la mayor parte de los factores macroeconómicos que han contribuido a acelerar la recuperación económica continuarán teniendo un impacto posi­ tivo sobre el crecimiento. Como puede apreciarse en el cuadro,

los grandes factores explicativos tanto del proceso recesivo co­ mo de la expansión son, en mi opinión, cuatro: el crecimiento de nuestro entorno económico inmediato, la evolución de la com­ petitividad externa de la peseta, el aumento de los salarios reales y los niveles de tipos de interés reales. La dinámica de estos factores es imparable, tanto para bien, como para mal. Para mal, porque cuando los salarios reales cre­ cen por encima de las ganancias de productividad del sistema, los tipos de interés reales se enquistan en niveles de vértigo y la apreciación del tipo de cambio real de la peseta provoca pérdi­ das de cuota de mercado doméstico e impide ganarlas en el mer­ cado exterior, los beneficios empresariales se laminan y con ellos la posibilidad de prosperar. Para bien, porque cuando los salarios reales se moderan, la reducción de tipos de interés rea­ les alivia la carga financiera de las empresas y las devaluaciones nominales del tipo de cambio restauran toda la competitividad perdida y la única respuesta posible es el espectacular creci­ miento registrado por las exportaciones en 1994, y con él, el re­ lanzamiento de la actividad y la inversión. Si dejamos a un lado la evolución de los tipos de interés reales en 1995, los cuales experimentarán un pequeño aumento, el resto de los factores es más que previsible que continúen teniendo un fa­ vorable impacto sobre el crecimiento económico español: el creci­ miento europeo se acelerará ampliando el potencial exportador de la economía española, no cabe anticipar una apreciación significati­ va del tipo de cambio real de la peseta, y los salarios reales no es probable que registren crecimiento alguno en 1995. Todo ello con­ duce a que la inversión se recupere y comience a generarse empleo. La cuarta y última razón para el optimismo la ofrece el his­ torial reformador del que puede hacer gala el actual Gobier­ no. Pese al evidente clima de crispación de la vida política es­ pañola, el Parlamento ha aprobado una importantísima Refor­ ma Laboral y ha concedido la autonomía al Banco de España para el diseño e instrumentación de la Política Monetaria, en­ comendándole como objetivo prioritario de sus actuaciones la defensa de la estabilidad de precios. Ambas decisiones repre­ sentan un cambio estructural respecto a nuestro pasado inme­ diato que diluye los temores sobre la incapacidad integral de hacer frente a las reformas estructurales de un Gobierno sin mayoría absoluta. Todo lo anterior confirmaría, en mi opinión, el mantenimien­ to de la recuperación en 1995, permitiéndonos subtitular esta co­ laboración con el Aquest any també que aparece en el encabeza­ miento. Los problemas no son para 1995, sino para después, si colectivamente no somos capaces de hacer converger la tasa de inflación con la de nuestro entorno y el déficit público continúa poniendo presión sobre los mercados financieros. Resolver ambos problemas exige llevar a cabo reformas es­ tructurales que tienen efectos redistributivos a los que sería in­ sensato no aparejar, en el corto plazo, costes políticos. Pero te­ mer ese resultado.no impedirá que la postergación de las refor­ mas necesarias deje de pasar factura: sin menos inflación y sin menos gasto público no será posible mantener a la economía es­ pañola en tasas de crecimiento del 3­3,5 por ciento, el tiempo suficiente para absorber nuestra elevadísima tasa de paro, por lo que el deseo de ver acortada nuestra brecha de prosperidad res­ pecto a Europa se vería frustrado. ■ JOSÉ JUAN RUIZ Técnico Comercial y Economista del Estado Consejo Editorial de Actualidad Económica y Expansión La tercera razón para el optimismo proviene de la evidente recuperación de la confianza tanto por parte de los consumido­ res, como por parte de los empresarios. J> Pascal Drouhaud, conseiller auprès du président du groupe d'études sur la démocratie en Amérique centrale à l'Assemblée nationale Depuis plusieurs décennies, la France entretient avec l'Amérique latine une relation qui semble être le fruit d'un héritage que l'on pourrait qualifier de contrasté. En effet, il allie atouts et faiblesses et révèle qu'il a toujours existé un décalage entre l'offre et la demande, entre l'espoir d'une présence française représentant une possibilité d'alternative à la présence nord-américaine et la mise en pratique de cette conception. Les relations se sont surtout fondées sur la proximité culturelle, qui n'a cependant pas engendré de véritables liens avec le monde économique. En outre, la France s'est parfois laissée enfermer dans son image de havre historique des droits de l'homme, jouissant d'une rente dans l'imaginaire collectif qui a pu la couper des forces vives de ces pays pour des raisons politiques. Aujourd'hui, l'Amérique latine a changé. Partout, le retour à la démocratie est effectif. Des politiques d'assainissement des économies ont été appliquées, permettant à cette région du monde d'assurer son grand retour au sein de l'économie mondiale. L'Amérique latine n'est pas homogène : il existe des Amériques latines en raison des différences ethniques, linguistiques et économiques qui peuvent favoriser l'émergence de pôles plus attractifs que d'autres en sön sein. C'est pourquoi il n'est pas possible de parler de relations bilatérales que la France entretiendrait avec le continent latino-américain dans son ensemble, mais de rapports multilatéraux, à géométrie variable selon les pays et les régions concernés. La France peut avoir un rôle important dans le cadre des rapports que l'Union européenne entretient avec l'Amérique latine. Il n'est jamais suffisamment rappelé que l'Union participe à hauteur de 2,7 milliards de dollars à l'aide économique envers cette région du monde qui ne bénéficie que de 1,5 milliard de la part des Etats-Unis. Quant à la France, elle accorde 20 % du total des crédits communautaires. L'Amérique latine est devenue un partenaire économique en croissance constante auprès duquel la France doit déployer une politique d'image afin de faire apparaître ce qu'elle est, à savoir une puissance économique mondiale engageant une action de partenariat avec d'autres acteurs, Etats ou Unions économiques de poids. En outre, les Etats-Unis faisaient leur apparition sur le marché culturel. Dans les aspirations des universitaires, les masters remplaçaient les maîtrises et les docto rats. Bien que distendus, les liens de la France avec le continent sud-américain ont connu des moments forts. La visite du générai De Gaulle en 1964 compte parmi les plus marquants. Mais, inca pable de concrétiser son discours, la France a sans doute engendré une certaine déception : il apparaissait qu'elle n'avait pas les moyens de sa politique dans cette région du monde. La France tenta un retour par le biais de la politique, au début des années 1980. La déclaration française du sommet de Cancún, au Mexique, en octobre 1981, qui légitimait l'action des mouvements de guérilla en Amérique centrale, en est l'exemple parfait. Mais l'échec de cette voie fut patent. La saisie de la situation latino-américaine à travers un prisme idéologique a plutôt contribué à renforcer l'amenuisement du rôle écono mique de la France sur ce continent. II existait une certaine incompréhension dans les relations que la France entretenait avec les Etats latino-américains, comme le démontrèrent leurs réactions après la déclaration de 1981. Des bases économiques restaurées Depuis la fin des années 1980, l'Amérique latine s'est engagée sur la voie d'une meilleure gestion de son économie. Durant "la décennie perdue", le produit intérieur brut (PIB) était en recul de 1,1 %. Les réformes structurelles adoptées petit à petit à partir de la seconde moitié des années 1980 ont favorisé le retour à une croissance. Cette dernière a été de 3 % en 1991, de 2,3 % en 1992, de 3,2 % en 1993 (1). Les gouvernements latino-américains se sont engagés sur la voie d'une maîtrise de l'inflation. Son taux moyen était de 160 % en 1991, il n'était plus que de 19 % en 1993. Ces Etats ont favorisé la libéralisation de l'économie, l'ouverture des frontières et réta bli l'équilibre des finances publiques. Ce problème était sans doute l'un des plus urgents tant le poids de la dette hypothéquait tout espoir de relance. Le protectionnisme et le dirigisme n'ont plus cours. Il ont fait place aux privatisations (2), aux déréglementations et surtout a la recherche d'une intégration économique régionale. L'ALENA, au Nord, côtoie le MERCOSUR, le Groupe des trois, le Pacte Andin et le SICA (3). Ces changements profonds permettent le retour massif des inves tissements directs étrangers. Ils ont été multipliés par trois entre 1986 et 1991, passant de 5,3 à 15,3 milliards de dollars. Cet investissement étranger est perçu comme un facteur favorisant l'épargne nationale mais aussi comme le moyen de moderniser l'appareil productif. Parallèlement, l'importation des biens d'équipement modernes est relancée. D'autre part, la dynamique communautaire se traduit par un abaissement important des tarifs douaniers. Pour l'année 1994, la CEPAL a indiqué que l'Amérique latine connaîtrait une croissance moyenne de l'ordre de 3 %, une hausse de 1 % du produit national brut (PNB) par habitant. (1) Données de la CEPAL (Commission économique pour l'Amérique latine et les Caraïbes, Nations unies). Rapport de 1994. (2) Par exemple, au Mexique, le nombre d'entreprises publiques est passé de 1 200 à la fin des années 1980 à 200 en 1992. (3) L'ALENA, Accord de libre échange nord-américain de 1993, réunit les Etats-Unis, le Canada, le Mexique. Le MERCOSUR. Marché commun du Sud, rassemble l'Argentine, le Brésil, le Paraguay et l'Uruguay depuis 1991. Le Groupe des trois, institué en 1989, est formé de la Colombie, du Mexique et du Venezuela. Le Pacte Andin, créé en 1969, comprend actuellement la Bolivie, la Colombie, l'Equateur, le Pérou et le Venezuela. Le SICA, Système d'intégration centraméricain. regroupe les pays d'Amérique centrale dans la perspective d'une union douanière, depuis 1993. Les transformations politiques Depuis la fin des années 1980, tous les régimes politiques latino-américains sont issus d'élections démocratiques. Le pro cessus d'implantation des principes démocratiques suit son cours. En 1993, le Paraguay, la Bolivie, le Venezuela, le Hon dura ont connu des élections nationales tout comme, en 1994, le Chili, le Brésil, le Mexique, le Panama, le Salvador, le Costa Rica. Certes, s'il est nécessaire de tempérer parfois l'optimisme que pourraient faire naître ces événements politiques qui profitent à l'idéal démocratique, il n'en reste pas moins vrai que la rupture avec les régimes forts des années 1980 est bien réelle. Mais les déséquilibres socio-économiques qui peuvent exister à l'inté rieur des frontières atténuent quelquefois la portée des résultats. La II ème Conférence internationale des démocraties nouvelles ou restaurées qui s'est tenue au Nicaragua durant le mois de juillet 1994 a bien montré combien réussir à faire participer tout un chacun aux bienfaits de la démocratie, aidé en cela par un retour de la croissance et une meilleure répartition de ses résultats, était important pour le succès de cette mutation politique. Les Etats latino-américains l'ont compris et se sont engagés dans la voie des réformes socio-économiques', tentant ainsi d'éviter de renforcer les poches de sous-développement qui existent et limitent la portée des réformes en créant une fracture dans la société. Cette évolution a permis de favoriser le retour de l'Amérique latine dans le tissu international et son insertion au sein du cou rant des échanges internationaux. L'Amérique latine : zone économique déclarée prioritaire par la France L'intérêt que la France porte à l'Amérique latine apparaît aujourd'hui à plusieurs niveaux. Le gouvernement français a déclaré l'Amérique latine zone économique prioritaire en 1993 au même rang que l'Asie du Sud-Est. Cette position devrait favoriser une coordination des différents secteurs intéressés par ce marché. C'est ainsi que s'est tenu en décembre 1993 le pre mier colloque France-Amérique latine à Paris, réunissant des acteurs institutionnels, des organisations non gouvernementales (ONG), des collectivités territoriales, des groupes industriels, tandis que la première table ronde sur le Cône Sud a rassemblé les acteurs concernés par le souci de renforcer les liens écono miques d'intérêt commun. Des lignes directrices commencent à apparaître : l'idée nouvelle est d'insister sur le fait qu'aujourd'hui les Etats ne sont plus les seuls maîtres du jeu et qu'il est nécessaire d'élargir aux collecti vités locales et aux associations les termes du débat. Le niveau des relations économiques que la France entretient avec l'Amérique latine est faible. Il représente 1,8 % des impor tations et des exportations françaises, 1 % des investissements français à l'étranger. Mais la volonté politique d'assurer un retour sur le marché latino-américain est affichée. Cet objectif peut être atteint par le biais des grands programmes multilaté raux engagés par les institutions internationales telles que la Banque interaméricaine de développement (BID), la Banque mondiale, la Banque européenne d'investissement (BEI), le Pro gramme des Nations unies pour le développement (PNUD). La France a décidé de définir les pôles économiques d'intérêt majeur concernant l'Amérique latine et de bâtir une stratégie d'ensemble en s'appuyant sur la concertation et la coordination des acteurs.

Atouts et objectifs français La France entretient en Amérique latine le réseau culturel le plus dense de son dispositif international. Ce dernier compte I 000 comités d'alliances françaises dans le monde. 700 d'entre eux se trouvent en Amérique latine, laquelle compte également 37 collèges et lycées français permettant la scolarisation de 22 000 élèves. La politique de la France a toujours consisté à gagner à soi une couche de la population appelée à occuper un jour des fonctions dirigeantes. C'est pourquoi il importe de maintenir le pôle d'excellence que constituent les établissements français et les Alliances qui sensibilisent un public plus large que les premiers. La France investit aujourd'hui 200 millions de francs dans ce dispositif. Mais elle cherche à favoriser le développement de nouveaux instruments de diffusion du français, à savoir TV5 et Canal France International. Depuis 1992, 700 000 nouveaux abonnés au câble ont été recensés. D'autre part, Radio France Internationale joue un rôle essentiel sur les ondes. Tous ces éléments convergent vers un objectif précis : faire du français une langue rénovée, moderne. Elle doit être un messa ger économique, l'allié de l'esprit d'entreprise afin que ses émetteurs puissent facilement s'insérer dans le tissu économique le plus dynamique. Ces orientations constituaient la finalité du contenu du sommet francophone de Québec en 1987 qui avait relevé le défi de faire du français la langue du développement économique du XXI èmc siècle. La réalité culturelle constitue le support d'un vaste ensemble dont les lignes directrices ont été définies par le ministre des Affaires étrangères en décembre 1993. La relance de la présence française en Amérique latine dépend de l'action entreprise pour favoriser l'implantation des entre prises, renforcer l'aide au développement et faire des Etats latino-américains des partenaires économiques reconnus par la communauté internationale. Sur le plan économique, il s'agit d'encourager l'implantation de l'Etat de droit et de contribuer au renforcement des dialogues régionaux déjà engagés sinon institués comme le sont ceux de San José en Amérique centrale, depuis 1984. et du Groupe des trois en Amérique du Sud. 300 millions de francs sont attribués à la coopération et de nou veaux secteurs d'actions sont définis. Tandis que l'agriculture et la san.'é composaient les deux grands volets de cet appui durant les années 1960, la recherche et l'informatique représentent aujourd'hui 31 % des crédits généraux de la coopération. L'agri culture voit sa part diminuer pour passer de 28 % en 1981 à 18 % en 1993 tandis que la santé couvre 15 % en 1993. Les nouveaux pôles concernent tout d'abord l'environnement qui voit ses crédits atteindre 12 % du total, en à peine cinq ans. II s'agit de participer aux politiques d'assainissement des eaux, de lutter contre la pollution dans les grandes métropoles et de garantir une bonne gestion dans l'exploitation des ressources naturelles. Le second secteur est celui de la formation aux métiers techniques, de la réforme des systèmes éducatifs, de la formation des hommes par rapport à leur engagement dans la refonte des instances organiques de l'Etat au profit du système démocratique. The former, therefore, repre sents a typical instance of a 'young' system, now in a advanced transitional phase and characterised by a tendency towards continuous population growth. The latter, instead, is an example of a 'mature' system, virtually stationary in that it is almost reaching the point of zero-growth. Alle caratteristiche peculiari di molti beni e servizi di pubblica utilità si è aggiunto, in Italia, il noto problema del ritardo del processo di sviluppo economico-industriale del paese e dell'inconsistenza del sistema delle imprese private. Così, nel settore delle public utilities si è fatto ampio ricorso a fenomeni di collettivizzazione, nel rispet to di precisi dettati costituzionali (artt. 41 e 43), laddove alcuni beni o servizi fossero ritenuti di imprescindibile rilevanza allo sviluppo nazionale. Federalism as an ideology and a political movement was born in Ventotene out of the awareness that fascism had been an extreme and desperate attempt of the nation­state, and of parasitic interests connected to it, to perpetuate their own existence by imposing à totalitarian regime and exalting nationalism, in the face of the irresistible historical trend to create ever larger areas of democratic government, caused by the continu­ ous increase of interdependence among people. Federalism opposed this crude and tribal ideology, which was based on hatred and discrimination, with the historic plan of suppressing war and oppression by overcoming national sovereignty and by creating international democracy, initially in a European, then in a world framework. Federalism, then, is not only different from fascism, but its exact opposite. If we heed closely the idealistic roots of our political commit­ ment, we can not declare ourselves to be anti­fascists and federalists, but rather anti­fascists because we are federalists. Anti­fascism, in the real meaning of the term, and federalism are the same thing. However, while for consciously­experienced federalism the identifi­ cation with anti­fascism is complete, it is also true that the values of the resistance are objectively the idealistic basis on which the Italian republic was constructed; and that these values inspired that section of the political class that knew how to place and maintain (albeit not without weak­ nesses, delays and hypocrisy) Italy on the rails of European unification and of Atlantic co­operation. In this way a country that the war brought on by fascism had reduced to a pile of ruins, was guaranteed almost half a century of peace, and with peace the possibility to grow in liberty and prosperity. Italy has recently witnessed a phenomenon without precedent in post­ second world war Europe: the formation of a government which includes members of a neo­fascist party (Alleanza Nazionale — National Alli­ ance). This is a fact that the federalists should analyse with great care, because their judgement on this aspect of the current political framework calls into question their identity, and hence their very existence. In fact Alleanza Nazionale denies being a neo­fascist grouping. Yet its essential component is the Movimento Sociale Italiano (Italian Social Movement), a party founded post­war on unequivocally neo­fascist po­ licies, and which has never subsequently abandoned them, even though it has always been divided into hard­line and "respectable" wings. In light of its inclusion in the government, Alleanza Nazionale has strongly emphasised its moderate nature. Today many of its leaders adopt posi­ tions that are much more reasonable than those of numerous members of

the extreme currents to be found in many European conservative parties that are often in power in their respective countries, and whose commit ment to democracy no-one would consider denying. It is true that there has remained within Alleanza Nazionale a group ing that openly harks back to fascism, and that the declarations of the party leaders themselves are far from unambiguous. Yet this ambiguity could be interpreted as the price that the more responsible leaders are obliged to pay to lead the party into the fold of a moderate right-wing movement that recognises and accepts the principles of democracy and that allows for the creation in Italy of a healthy alternation between a conservative line-up and a progressive one, as happens in Anglo-Saxon democracies and, even if in an imperfect way, in the other democracies of Western Europe. To this can be added the fact that, on the basis of opinion polls, only a negligible percentage of Alleanza Nazionale voters declare themselves to be fascist, and that anyway Alleanza Nazionale is a minority partner in the government coalition. Within the coalition, the component that won the strongest support in terms of votes, "Forza Italia", despite having concluded an electoral as well as governmental alliance with Alleanza Nazionale, and despite having repeatedly ex pressed disturbing populist and nationalistic attitudes in some of its policy declarations, has never formally questioned its commitment to the values of liberty and democracy. However the idea that Alleanza Nazionale could transform itself into a component of a grand right-wing democratic grouping, without ceasing to exist, is hardly credible. All political movements live in a continuum, drawing on the memory of their origins for the force to pursue their own projects. They have therefore an insuperable element of inertia that is linked to the nature of the choice out of which they were founded, and that conditions, over and above the alterations brought about by the need to tailor themselves to an evolving situation, the way in which their militants perceive the motivation of theircommon commitment. Currently, Alleanza Nazionale is the point of arrival of an evolutionary process that began in neo-fascism, and it would not exist without the latter: a neo-fascism that can not be denied without repudiating the movement's past and hence its identity, on which depends its very existence. It is often said in Italy that a rejection of Alleanza Nazionale is an indication of sectarianism, because, on the opposite side of the political spectrum, the communists have been legitimised as part of the democratic political line-up despite being the descendants of Stalinism. That the memory of Stalin has placed obstacles in the way of those who opted to bring communism back into the enclave of democracy is a matter of fact. And it is right that this was so, because the atrocities of Stalinism were as cruel as those of nazism, and without a doubt considerably more cruel than those of Italian fascism. There remains, however, the fact that communism originated in the proletariat's struggle to emancipate itself in the name of the universal ideals of equality between people and liberation from want. Stalinism was, then, a tragic degenerative episode of a movement that in its founding ideals provided a vital contribution to the political culture of mankind and to its process of emancipation. Fascism, on the other hand, was founded on the negative values of man's oppression of man, of national hatred and of intolerance. It is for this reason that some ex-communist parties have been able, with much effort, to legitimise themselves again by a return to their original values and the rejection of the degenerative episodes that have stained their history, while this option is not open to movements of fascist origin. And this is why the trend towards the polarisation of political life that is currently manifesting itself in Italy is unhealthy.

17 Italy is unlikely, in the short term, to risk any real danger of a fascist regression. Yet it remains a fact that the future of Italian democracy depends on the solidity of the European framework, which is the precondition for the Italian economy's capacity to keep step, one way or another, with the other advanced economies; and that the European framework would be greatly weakened if the national-populist trends in the foreign and economic policy of one of the Community's founding countries, that had until now been one of the most explicit and consistent supporters of its federal vocation, were reinforced. In any event, Italian society is from now on running the real danger of the trivialisation of fascism, that is of the end of anti-fascism. It is disturbing to note how nowadays in Italy arguments such as that the opposition between fascism and anti-fascism has by now been consigned to history, and that it is time to undertake the task of "national reconciliation", are being given serious consideration. Such a formula attempts to put on an equal plane the reconciliation between people (that is an inexistent problem, if for no other reason than because those that personally experienced the drama of the fall of fascism, and of the resistance, are old or dead) and a compro mise between the values of liberty and democracy, and their negation. Values (and their opposites) do not die, nor do they grow old; nor can they be separated from the judgement of events and movements through which they have historically manifested themselves. The great idealistic affirmations of the French revolution have become the everlasting patrimony of the human race. Conversely the historic identification of fascism with dictatorship and nationalist violence can not be erased by the passing of time. Those who currently pretend to profess the values of liberty and democracy without simultaneously rejecting their negation, as it has concretely manifested itself in history, are not credible because they remain prisoners of an incurable contradiction. It is difficult in today's Italy to escape the deep unease that provokes the observation that for many people fascism has become an idea like any other — that like other ideas it has a right to a place in political debate. Above all other considerations, the spread of this attitude is an indication of the dramatic worsening of the crisis of Italian political life that has coincided with last April's profound changes in the political landscape, in which many wanted to see the dramatic breakthrough of something "new". A serious indication of this crisis lies precisely in the fact that in the current Italian government, nationalistic and anti-European positions are gaining ground, even if inevitably attenuated and rendered ambiguous by the awareness that no national policy can be carried forward today in Europe without some form of co-operation among the states of the European Union. And if it is true that nationalism is always and every where a regressive phenomenon that turns its back on the future, it is a sign of a profound civil malaise and of a very serious rejection of values in a country such as Italy, where the war against fascism was not fought as a national war, as was the case in Great Britain and to a certain extent in France, but where, on the contrary, nation and fascism have been historically identified as one and the same thing. It is true that April's electoral earthquake had specific causes, the most evident of which was the reaction of public opinion against the corruption of the parties that had governed Italy in the post-war decades. But it is necessary strenuously to guard against the temptation to confuse the historical understanding of a phenomenon with its moral justification. In politics there is a time to understand and a time to judge. It should not be forgotten that nazism also had specific historical causes, yet that understanding them does not render nazism itself less odious.

The political parties of the first republic largely betrayed their ideologies by their concrete actions, and were jointly responsible for the progressive degeneration of Italian political life — even if this phenom enon has not been only Italian, and even if its ultimate cause should be identified in the inability of Kuropean governments and political forces as a whole to lead the process of continental unification to a federal conclusion. But their ideologies, whose roots lie in the great civil struggles of the 19th century and the first years of the 20th, however much they were professed superficially and hypocritically, forced Italy's post war political parties to orient themselves in political debate with regard to values, to seek legitimisation and continuity in their own historical past, and to try to delineate perspectives for the future. For this reason these parties, although not all at the same time, came to recognise themselves unreservedly in the ideal of European unity and they spread acceptance of this to almost the whole of public opinion. Today on the other hand, after the dramatic breakthrough of the "new", the reference to values, to history and to the future has simply disappeared from politics, substituted by crude and provincial nationalistic outbursts and by a pragmatism that is only a screen for a lack of ideas. Today's Italy is worse than the bad Italy of yesterday. Some argue that they can not condemn the presence of neo-fascists in the Italian government, asserting that this is the result of the democratic expression of the Italian people's will, and as such must be respected. If by that the aim is to state that this disturbing phenomenon should be combated with the tools of democracy, then the argument is simply obvious. But if the argument is used to legitimise the neo-fascists politically, it should be rejected. Moreover, if it were sound, it would serve to legitimise historically the fascist and nazist regimes, which rose to power using the tools of democracy. The truth is that in today's Europe, the states, to recall one of Einaudi's famous expressions, are dust without substance. And dust without substance are also the national peoples. The Italian people can not express any will because it has simply ceased to exist, in as much as within the Italian framework there no longer exist real alternatives from which to make a choice. Or rather, the Italian people continue to exist only as part of the European people-in-the-making, as do the other peoples of the European states, and only in this form can they express their will, regain the capacity to pursue projects and possess again an authentic historical understand ing. The something "new" of which in today's Italy there is so much talk, most of it superficial and hypocritical, will emerge only when a political grouping is formed on the basis of the awareness that the change on which Italy's and Europe's salvation depends is that which consists specifically of giving expression to the European federal people that is in the process of coming about. Yet politicians, old and new alike, are prisoners of the contests of the past and obstinately refuse to recognise this. The Federalist * * * **

Introduction The Italian tax legislator, introducing a third paragraph in Article 37 of the decree on income assessment 1 has laid the foundations for the consideration of tax avoidance schemes involving the insertion of a third party into the transaction ('interposition'). As far as this paper is concerned, this theme is not devoid of international implications. In fact, Article 30 of the Decree law of 2 March 1989, No. 69, as modified by the Law of 27 April 1989, No. 154, provides as follows: 'In case of adjustment of the assessed income, or of assessment by the tax-office, a taxpayer may be charged with an income apparently chargeable to another party, provided that the above mentioned taxpayer be the actual owner of the said income through this third party'. The purpose of this provision, as it can be inferred from the title of this legislative measure, 2 is of course to tax the principal taxpayer by ignoring certain schemes used to minimize his income tax (substance over form). This means that we are here considering a specific anti-avoidance rule within the framework of a tax legal order (the Italian one) that does not include, at the present time, an anti-avoidance Generalklausel. The main point of the provision in question turns on the meaning in the legislation of the term 'interposition' (interposizione) or the insertion of a third party. Before finding a solution to this problem, it is necessary to analyze the varying aspects of the problem, and-at the same time - identify the transactions it affects especially those with an international character. 2. The Meaning of Interposition As a first approach to the problem, it is easy enough to ascertain the general meaning of the word 'interposition'. Interposition, in fact, means of course 'putting something between', i.e. the action by which an intermediate element is introduced between two opposite ends. Accordingly, the interposition of a third party in a legal transaction results in income which should be charged to the principal A being charged to the third party B. 3 However the above is not a sufficient analysis of the term in this case, Italian civil law assumes at least two different situations as to the structure and legal implication of a transaction, which must be kept separate. Sometimes the legal effect of a transaction seems to involve B, while the actual but hidden party in charge of it is, since the beginning, A; sometimes the effect involves B, and actually does so but this is only an intermediate step before another transaction is entered into which passes the property or income to A. It is clear that the transaction structure of the two hypotheses is deeply different. They share a common element, i.e. principal A uses third party B, with whom the legal effect of the transaction(s) seems to rest. In the first case, however, appearance does not correspond to reality, and the intention is to conceal the actual principal; on the contrary, in the second case a true intermediate transfer is performed and the actual aim of the transaction is not necessarily concealed. After these premises, it is clearly understandable why in Italian law the two cases are distinguished, and are given two different definitions, i.e. 'fictitious interposition' and 'actual interposition'. In fact, only in the second case does the intermediate third party assume legal rights in respect of the transaction(s). 4 The reason for the usual term by which the so called

20 interposed party is defined in the first case is obvious as well: the terms 'prestanome' (i.e. he who lets his name appear to conceal someone else's name), or 'passacarte' are the Italian equivalents for the English 'strawman', or the German 'Strohmann'. On the other hand, the reason for recognizing the parties' simulation is clear enough: someone is simulating something which is not true. As a partial example, though sticking to the theoretical side of the manner and postponing to later on in this paper the examination of some concrete cases conceived on the basis of the specific provisions of the Italian tax law, we can look at the two following cases. Party A wants to carry out a certain profitable transaction and, at the same time, does not want to charge the results to its own taxable income, so it decides to use Β (a controlled company, for example). After this, an agreement between A, B, and C is entered into, according to which the transaction shall apparently be performed by Β and C, while the economic and legal effects flow to A. From a fiscal point of view, this could mean that profits deriving from the transactions entered into by Β will be taxed in B's hands instead of A's resulting in a saving of tax for A. This is an example of a 'fictitious imposition'. An example of an 'actual interposition' is where, for any reason whatsoever, an unfavour­ able tax-effect results from the establishment of a direct relationship between A and C. s In this case A can effect the transaction in question with Β and obtain from B, at the same time, an undertaking to transfer to C the results of the said transaction by means of an autonomous action. We report results from a comparison of interindustry wage differentials in Germany and the United States based on large sets of individual data and controlling for a number of personal characteristics. 1. Introduction Recent efforts to resolve the industry wage differentials puzzle have uncovered an abundance of evidence on the structure of wages. While most of the research centers on data from a single country 1 ), Krueger and Summers (1987), Katz and Summers (1989), and Wagner (1990) have compared wage structures across international boundaries. Using aggregate data on hourly and monthly wages in 1982, Krueger and Summers (1987) found very high correlations of wages in fourteen countries: The correlations between the U.S. and the highly industrialized countries (Japan, France, Canada, Germany, UK, Norway and Sweden) ranged from .67 to .93. Katz and Summers (1989) also examined aggregate data, using yearly and hourly wages of manufacturing operatives in 1983 in nine countries, and found correlations for the U.S. and the other countries ranging from .66 to .95, with the two lowest correlations related to lesser developed countries. Katz and Summers (1989) infer from this evidence that "wage differences result from factors fundamental to the operation of industrial economies and are not the artifact of particular collective bargaining systems or government interventions in the labor market." An unfortunate aspect of the data used in these comparisons across countries is that they are ill-suited for analysis that holds constant factors such as education and experience, or for comparisons based on more homogenous groups of workers that are not as influenced by such factors as discrimination. The Krueger and Summers (1987) study has the advantage that some of the correlations are based on samples that only include men. Wagner (1990) is able to control for individual characteristics, as the results are based on microdata, but the study is limited by small sample sizes. Wagner (1991), Moll (1991), Stegwee (1990), Zanchi (1991) and Arai (1990) confirm with microdata that wage differentials do indeed exist among workers in other countries. These studies use microdata to analyze wages in Germany, South Africa, the U.K., and Sweden. Generally, the dispersion of wages, after controlling for such factors as education, experience, and union status, was found to be smaller than in the United States, but nevertheless large. However, these results do not speak directly to the issue of whether interindustry wage differentials are similar across industry countries. Such evidence on the structure of wages in various countries would provide important information on the nature of industry wage differentials, and enhance our understand ing of the considerations these differentials might have for industrial policy in open economies (c. Katz and Summers, 1989).

25 This study compares the structures of wages in the U.S. and Germany using microdata from wage surveys in 1979,1985, and 1987. The samples include data on white, male, full-time, workers, thereby constituting a much more homogenous group of workers than is typically available for study. After controlling for a number of personal characteristics, including education, time on the job (tenure), regional factors, and experience in the work force, average industry wages are estimated and compared for the two countries. In contrast to Katz and Summers (1989) and Krueger and Summers (1987), who found correlations of .95 and .85, respectively, between industry average wages in Germany and the U.S., the evidence presented here suggests correlations generally near .6 but as low as .22. While these correlations are still fairly high, they suggest that the structure of wages is not quite as uniform across countries as previous studies might have indicated. The next section discusses the estimations and their results. Our conclusions are presented in the third and final section. 3. Conclusions This microdata study of industry wage differentials in Germany and the United States finds fairly high correlations between the two countries' wage structures. The correlations are, however, not as great as those found by earlier researchers using more heterogenous and aggregated data sets. The differences in the correlations do not appear to be the result only of including control variables' that are available in a microdata sample, as the correlations based on aggregation of our own samples are quite high and not greatly different from those based on regression estimates. A possible explanation for the differences in our correlations and those found in previous studies is that our datasets are more restrictive. In order to arrive at the most homogenous group of workers possible, we restricted our samples to full-time, white males who are not self-employed, disabled, retired, or mainly occupied as students. In contrast, the data used by Krueger and Summers (1987), who found a correlation of wage differentials of .85, include all workers covered by the ILO Yearbook of Labor Statistics surveys. While the results of our research indicate that there are similarities in interindustry wage differentials across international boundaries, these similarities are found mainly in industries that pay the lowest wages, such as agriculture, education, leather goods, lumber products, and government. ECU aus dem EFRE für arbeitsplatzsichernde und -schaffende gewerbliche Investitionen und unter stützende Infrastrukturmaßnahmen so wie 11,3 Mio. ECU aus dem ESF zur Durchführung von Umschulung, Fort bildung, Weiterbildung und Beratung vorgesehen. Dabei obliegt den Landes ministerien und -behörden gemeinsam die Makroplanung und Koordinierung, während die eigentliche Vernetzung, also die Feinabstimmung von Projek ten, auf Landkreisebene zu erfolgen hat. Unterstützend wurden auf Landkreis ebene projektbegleitende Büros, sog. "Centren für ländliche Information und Kommunikation" eingerichtet. Bis herige Erfahrungen zeigen, daß es zu Anfang Implementationsschwierig keiten bei dem koordinierten Einsatz der beteiligten drei Fonds gab, die teilweise auf Defizite der Makroebene (unzureichende Kompatibilität zwi schen einzelnen bestehenden Förder richtlinien, teilweise fehlende Landes richtlinien) oder der Landkreisebene (Defizite bei der Zusammenarbeit der regionalen/lokalen Akteure) zurück zuführen waren. Um einen raschen Mittelabfluß zu gewährleisten, wurden die EG-Strukturfondsmittel über wiegend nach den Richtlinien der beiden Gemeinschaftsaufgaben einge setzt. Dies schränkte das förderfähige Maßnahmenspektrum ein. Durch eine unzureichende Vernetzung von Projek ten auf Landkreisebene wurden mög liche Synergiewirkungen nicht reali siert. Gerade die ganzheitliche Ziel setzung der "Integrierten ländlichen Entwicklung", den ländlichen Raum als Wirtschafts-, Natur- und Sozial raum zu erhalten und dies durch entsprechende Fördermaßnahmen zu unterstützen, konnte so bisher nur bedingt verwirklicht werden. Erste positive Ansätze sind aber zu erkennen. Es wurde eine interministerielle Ar beitsgruppe "Ländlicher Raum" ins Leben gerufen, so daß zukünftig eine bessere Makroplanung und Koordinie rung gewährleistet ist. Zunehmend gibt es eigene Branden burger Landesrichtlinien, die den Bedürfnissen des ländlichen Raumes stärker angepaßt sind, wie z.B. die Richtlinie zur Förderung von "Urlaub und Freizeit auf dem Lande". Die "Centren für ländliche Information und Kommunikation" werden auch 1994 weiterbestehen und könnten einen Bei trag zu einer Abstimmung der einzel nen Akteure auf Landkreisebene leisten. Im nächsten Programmpla nungszeitraum im Rahmen der EG- Strukturpolitik 1994 bis 1999 ist zwar kein spezieller Programmpunkt "Inte grierte ländliche Entwicklung" vor gesehen. Es sollen aber regionale Schwerpunkte der Förderung in den ländlichen Problemregionen Prignitz, Uckermark, Fläming und Oderbruch gesetzt werden, für die komplexe Entwicklungsprogramme erarbeitet werden. Der Wirksamkeit strukturpolitischer Maßnahmen nach dem Leitbild der "Dezentralen Konzentration" und dem ergänzenden Konzept der "Integrierten Ländlichen Entwicklung" sind auf grund der augenblicklich ungünstigen konjunkturellen Situation und auch an gesichts der mittelfristig verhaltenen Wachstumsperspektiven zur Vermin derung regionaler Disparitäten enge Grenzen gesetzt. Erfahrungen aus den alten Bundesländern zeigen, daß die Möglichkeit der Beeinflussung der regionalen Kapitalbildung primär von den gesamtwirtschaftlichen Rahmen bedingungen abhängt. Besonders in Zeiten von hohen Wachstumsraten und Vollbeschäftigung konnte regionale Strukturpolitik durch eine gezielte Beeinflussung des Rentabilitätsgefal- les zugunsten des ländlichen Raumes Einfluß auf die Standortbildung neh men. So konnten auch diese Regionen vom Wachstum in den Ballungsräumen profitieren (19). Für den Gesamtraum Brandenburg/Berlin bedeutet dies unter der Perspektive ungünstiger gesamtwirtschaftlicher Rahmenbedin gungen, daß schon als ein großer Erfolg regionaler Agrar- und Wirtschafts strukturpolitik zu werten ist, wenn sich der Abstand des ländlichen Raumes zu der Region Berlin-Brandenburg nicht weiter vergrößert. * * * **

33 A COMPARATIVE STUDY OF INHERITANCE AND GIFT TAXES Introduction By Dr J.F. Avery Jones* I am very pleased to introduce this survey of taxation of inheritance and gifts in the twelve EC Member States, Austria, Switzerland, Monaco, the Nordic countries and thé United States. I have long felt that inheritance and gifts taxes were a neglected topic. It is certainly one about which information can be hard to obtain and I hope it will prove to be an extremely useful survey. As can be seen from this survey, all the countries repre sented rely on some form of taxation on inheritance and gifts. If a country does want to tax capital as well as income, it is better that it should do so when capital changes hands, rather than annually as with an annual wealth tax. It seems, however, that many countries, includ ing Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Luxembourg, Norway, Spain, Sweden and Switzerland,' impose both an inheritance and an annual wealth tax. The disadvantage of a wealth tax compared to an inheritance tax is that wealth, particularly in the form of a business, is depleted as it is built up. Even an inheritance tax is a problem for business assets which are not capable of being marketed in order to pay the tax. Many states give some reliefs for business assets (including Finland, France, Greece, Ireland, the Netherlands, Norway, Sweden). The United Kingdom goes further by effectively exempting business assets from the tax, but this causes a big discrepancy between business assets and other assets and is probably not a stable solution in the long term. One suspects that many countries do not actually tax the real market value of a business. Reliefs are found in the valuation of non-business assets, forexample, Sweden takes only 75% of the quoted value of shares. It is noticeable how little revenue is collected in inheri tance taxes. Most countries represented report a yield of 1% or less of tax revenue, although Germany is much higher with 4.2%. TAXATION OF WORLDWIDE ASSETS Most countries charge tax on inheritance and on gifts on two grounds: worldwide taxation based on the connection of the taxpayer with the country and assets situated in the country. Under the former, tax is charged on worldwide assets on the basis of the connection of the taxpayer (I shall deal below with whether the taxpayer for this pur pose is the donor or donee) with the country, whether this connection is citizenship, domicile or residence. Portugal and Monaco are the only exceptions among the countries represented as they tax only on a situs basis. In giving examples of countries I have not necessarily been comprehensive and I shall not repeat in each case that I am merely giving examples. foreign immovable property is not included (Finland, Greece, the Swiss cantons and Luxembourg); this used to be common but most countries now tax foreign immov able property. The foundation of worldwide taxation is the taxpayer's connection with the country; this connection can be either residence, domicile or nationality. Residence, based per haps on six months' presence, which may be right for tax ing one year's income, is much less apposite for charging lifetime capital, but many states use it as the connecting factor. Denmark is interesting in having a different defini tion of residence for this purpose, requiring a more perma nent connection than residence for income tax, and com mentators in Sweden are of the view that there is a similar rule there; the concept of residence for inheritance tax has developed separately from income tax in Luxembourg. The common law countries' (United States, United King dom, Ireland) use of domicile, even though slightly differ ently applied in each country, is perhaps fairer in looking for the ultimate country with which the person is connect ed, but it is difficult to apply in practice. If one needs proof of that, the UK rule that a person is deemed to be domi ciled for inheritance tax from the beginning of year 17 of residence demonstrates how difficult it is for a person to become domiciled there and hence how difficult it is for tax to be collected from foreigners living in the country. Nationality is used as an important connection in the United States, Norway and Greece and ensures that the estates of non-resident nationals are taxed, although Nor way exempts estates from inheritance tax if the residence state taxes them. Sweden ceased to use nationality as a basis for taxation in 1989. Current connection with a coun try is not the only criterion. Because residence is easy to lose many states have a period, often as long as ten years (Greece, Sweden and the Netherlands for nationals) dur ing which they continue to collect tax after the person has ceased to be a resident, or, in the case of the United States, a citizen. Shorter terms, such as five years after ceasing to be resident for German citizens, three years after ceasing to be domiciled in the United Kingdom, two years for Aus trian citizens and one year for gifts by non-nationals in the Netherlands, are also found. Other grounds for worldwide taxation are occasionally found, such as Denmark taxing estates subjected to pro bate in Denmark, regardless of the residence of the deceased, and the former Irish rule taxing them if the dis position was governed by Irish law. The donor and donee base An unusual feature of inheritance taxation, compared to income taxation, is that there are two competing bases, the donor and the donee bases, designating not who is liable to pay the tax, but by reference to whom the tax is calculated. Of the countries represented, the United States and the

34 United Kingdom, Italy as to one component of the tax, and some Swiss cantons, 2 tax on the basis of the donor, that is to say that the deceased has one rate scale however many beneficiaries there are and whoever they are. The rest of the countries tax on the basis of the donee, with as many rate scales (usually graduated by reference to the consan­ guinity of the beneficiary to the deceased) as there are be­ neficiaries, so that both the identity of the beneficiary and the amount of his receipt are relevant to the calculation of the tax. As a general rule, a donor base co-exists better with a system of law having executors, who step into the deceased's shoes and are responsible for paying the tax, coupled with the freedom of testamentary disposition existing in the common law countries; and a donee base co-exists better with property vesting in the heir under rules of compulsory heirship. A donor system caters more easily for trusts, under which the identity of the donee is unknown, which presumably accounts for the preference of the common law countries for this basis, although Ire­ land has managed to deal with the problems of trusts under a donee base. But neither the donor nor the donee system is found in a completely pure form. In a donor system, in many cases, such as bequests to spouses and charities, the identity of the donee and the amount a particular donee receives does matter and this increases the complications of the donor base compared to a donee base. One can, for example, have the situation in the United Kingdom of the tax payable out of residue on legacies left free-of-tax depend­ ing upon the amount of taxable residue, the size of which, if only part of the residue is taxable, in turn depends upon the amount of tax on the free-of-tax legacies; a problem which can be solved only by an iterative process. One might expect that a donee-based tax would tax by refer­ ence, to the connection of the donee with the taxing state, but in most cases of inheritance taxes, it is the donor's con­ nection which is relevant. Only Spain uses the donee's connection solely and Germany and Austria use either the donor's or the donee's connection. For taxation of gifts, however, it is sometimes the donee's connection which counts (e.g. Finland). Denmark taxes gifts on the basis of either the donor or the donee's residence; Greece taxes on the basis of either the donor's or the donee's nationality or residence; and in Sweden either the donor's or the donee's Swedish nationality is relevant to taxing some property. The donee basis is more akin to income tax which is charged on the recipient and the problems of double taxa­ tion are therefore better understood. One would expect the interaction of these two bases to create serious problems but this does not seem to occur, probably because most countries imposing a donee-based tax do so on the con­ nection of the donor with the taxing country, so that it is the same person who determines the connection with a state under both systems. The legal background Concurrently with problems of differing tax bases there exist the problems of legal bases governing succession which can interact with the tax liability particularly in countries with forced heirship provisions. I recently came upon Professor David Hay ton's memorable example of a deceased person domiciled in a common law State A, habitually resident in State Β (such as France, Belgium or Denmark) but a national of State C (e.g. Spain, Portugal, Germany, Austria, the Netherlands or Italy) owning immovable property in State D. The result is that each of the four states applies its own succession law to the assets in its state. 2. The Netherlands donee tax also has some donor-type features. Reliefs for spouses One would expect an inheritance tax to try to charge tax once each generation, which points to exempting transfers between spouses. This exemption is found only in the United States, the United Kingdom, Ireland, Denmark (for undivided estates), some Swiss cantons and Luxembourg and Monaco (in both of which exemption applies to inher­ itances by direct descendants as well as spouses), although additional deductions for spouses are found in France (and there is a more beneficial rate scale at the lower end), Fin­ land, Germany, Ireland, the Netherlands, Luxembourg (if the exemption does not apply), Sweden and Denmark. Most of the other countries charge tax on inheritance by spouses at the same rate as children and there are some countries, such as Norway, Spain and Portugal, which charge a lower rate on bequests to minor children (not only minor children in Norway) than to spouses. But these reliefs should be seen in the context of regimes of commu­ nity of property under which spouses share in a part of the estate automatically. So long as there are reliefs either as part of general law, or specifically in the tax system for transfers between spouses, inheritance tax falls on wealth being passed from one generation to another which is hard to oppose. Tax rates The range of tax rates is interesting, although one cannot directly compare the tax rates under a donor and a donee base. Most countries with donee taxes charge receipts by spouses and children at a rate up to about 30%, although there are higher rates in Spain (34%) and Germany (35%) and even higher rates in France and Ireland with a maxi­ mum 40% rate. In Spain there is also a surcharge based on the recipient's existing wealth. There are some extremely high rates for strangers, such as Denmark's 90% rate. In Finland there is a rate of inheritance tax for strangers of 42% plus local taxation up to 26.7%. TAXATION ON THE BASIS OF SITUS OF ASSETS IN THE COUNTRY The second ground for taxation, where there is no such connection of the taxpayer with the country, is on the basis of assets situated in the taxing country. As has been men­ tioned, this is the sole basis for taxation in Portugal and Monaco. The width of the charge varies considerably from taxing virtually all assets on the basis of situs (Finland, United states, United Kingdom, Ireland, France, Italy, Spain, Portugal, Greece), to having a list of the type of property which is taxed (Germany, Austria, Sweden for nationals), down to taxing only real property and business assets (the Netherlands (with a slightly wider list), Nor­ way, Sweden (but including, in addition to immovable property, shares in companies providing housing for share­ holders) for non-nationals and immovable property only in Belgium, Denmark, the Swiss cantons and Luxembourg). Sometimes gift taxes are effectively only charged on the basis of situs, as in Luxembourg (real property only) and Belgium (real property and property which cannot pass by delivery). DOUBLE TAXATION The problem The combination of domicile, citizenship and residence, to say nothing of the deemed continuation of domicile, resi­ dence and citizenship for up to 10 years, is a recipe for dis-

35 aster caused by several countries claiming worldwide tax ing rights. A deceased may be a US citizen, domiciled in (or deemed to be domiciled in) the United Kingdom, and resident in almost any other country represented, so that all three countries claim worldwide taxation. There can be more problems if countries do not agree on matters such as where the deceased was domiciled. Analogous to the problem of double residence (or its vari ants, such as domicile or citizenship) are the problems of determining the situs of assets which, in the case of intan gible assets, is notional, as pointed out in the chapter on the OECD Model Estate Tax Convention, and is often open to doubt. There is the problem that states may take a different view of what is the asset, involving whether an interest in a partnership, an unadministered estate or a trust is itself an asset or whether the interest is in the underlying assets. These problems can lead to claims of double situs, with two (or more) states saying that an asset is situated in their state, or even each saying that it is situated in the other. The combination of these factors means that the possibili ty of double or multiple taxation is as prevalent for inheri tance and gifts taxes as it is for income tax, but the result is far more serious because one is dealing with lifetime accu mulations of capital, rather than one year's income. The surprising thing is that one does not hear more about the problems of double taxation with inheritance and gifts taxes. Anecdotally there do not seem to be that many cases of serious double taxation but one feels that the competing jurisdiction of states ought to cause more of it. Is the rea son for this lack of concern about the problems of death taxes, the high degree of avoidance of tax imposed on a situs basis through the holding of assets through foreign companies or is it non-compliance, particularly in the inability of states to collect tax on most forms of assets on the basis of situs? If it is the latter, then the position could change with the OECD and Council of Europe multilater al convention which includes assistance in collection of inheritance taxes. But not many countries are adopting the treaty. Whatever the reason, the problems do exist and need study. The OECD Model and inheritance tax treaties The OECD Model double taxation convention on estates and inheritances and on gifts solves some of these prob lems by cutting down the situs charges to the minimum found in practice consisting of immovable property and permanent establishments of a business, thus leaving only the state of residence of the donor to levy tax on world wide property. Simultaneous claims to worldwide taxation are dealt with by dual residence articles on the same lines as for income tax. As pointed out in the chapter on the OECD Model there are still some problems which the Model does not solve. One would expect there to be a good treaty network by now, but there is not. Most of the countries represented have only about six or fewer treaties, although the United Kingdom and Switzerland have 10, the United States 16, and the record goes to Sweden with 17; but all these are far fewer than the number of income tax treaties found in most countries. The OECD has given a lead in providing a Model treaty in this area but, as is pointed out in the chap ter on the OECD Model, states are slow in implementing treaties based on it. Part of the problem may be that, because of the different bases of taxation, such treaties need to be tailor-made to a greater extent than income tax treaties and negotiations are therefore longer and more dif ficult. Spain, with a donee basis inheritance tax depending. unusually, on the residence of the donee, which is different from the basis on which the Model proceeds, has made only two treaties, which points to the difficulty of combin ing different bases. States understandably put their treaty negotiating resources into the areas of greatest demand, that is income tax treaties between major trading states, but this should not be to the exclusion of death duties treaties. Failing a good treaty network, and it is failure with which we must learn to live, a second best is that there needs to be a good system of unilateral relief. Again one is disap pointed. The Swiss cantons do not give any relief at all, apart from exempting real property which has been taxed abroad. Denmark and Belgium give credit only for taxes on foreign immovable property; taxes on other assets are relieved by deduction only. Austria gives only a deduction for foreign inheritance taxes, although the Ministry of Finance can give a credit where this is reciprocal. And in some cases the Netherlands gives only a deduction. Lux embourg is unusual in giving an exemption, rather than a credit, for foreign taxes. So far as I can see, the United Kingdom is still the only country which gives relief unilat erally for cases of double worldwide taxation, that is for taxes imposed not only by the country of situs but also by a third country. Admittedly this reduces its negotiating position in treaty making, but at least it obviates the need for treaties. But there are other advantages of treaties to states, such as exchange of information from the point of view of the tax authority, and cutting down the need to deal with two tax authorities and the advantages of having non-discrimination and mutual agreement provisions from the point of view of the taxpayer. The EC initiative It is pleasing to be able to conclude by noting that very recently the European Commission has published a com munication to the Council and the European Parliament which includes a statement that it will make proposals lim iting the tax charges on the transmission of businesses by gift and on death. 3 Extensive consultations are promised before making a recommendation. II. — PERSPECTIVES D'AVENIR DU TRIBUNAL INTERNATIONAL Pour la première fois depuis la seconde guerre mondiale, un instru ment juridique nécessaire à la mise en œuvre du droit international huma nitaire semble être disponible, sa base légale étant déjà bien développée. Enfin une question attire notre attention : celle portant sur les réels moyens d'action et les chances de succès du nouveau Tribunal international. A. — Difficultés de la poursuite pénale engagée par l'O. N. U. Plus difficile à surmonter que les objections strictement juridiques, des problèmes pratiques de police judiciaire risquent de nuire à l'exercice effectif de la répression internationale. II s'agit, par exemple, des diffé rents problèmes concernant l'instruction et l'administration des preuves effectuées par une Cour internationale dont le siège est éloigné du lieu où les crimes ont été commis, ou encore aux difficultés linguistiques des juges et à la crédibilité des témoins. L'expérience antérieure de la « Com mission 780 », prédécesseur du Tribunal, démontre la difficulté de rédiger des procès-verbaux probants même lorsqu'il s'agit de crimes aussi graves (96). En l'absence d'une police judiciaire internationale, le principal obs tacle au niveau de la procédure est celui de l'arrestation des criminels de guerre présumés. Comme le Tribunal n'est pas habilité à prononcer des jugements par contumace (97) (art. 21, § 4, al. d du Statut), les juges devront se contenter de lancer des mandats d'arrêt internationaux. Or les juges dépendront de la volonté politique des gouvernements (en parti culier de celle des gouvernements des cinq États successurs de la Yougos-

38 lavie) pour ce qui est de l'arrestation et de l'extradition des personnes recherchées vers le Tribunal à la Haye. Bien que les États soient obligés d'exécuter les mandats d'arrêt en vertu de l'article 29 du Statut et des articles 25 et 103 de la Charte (98), le Tribunal ne dispose d'aucun moyen pour renforcer cette obligation juridique. Et il reste à prouver que le Conseil de sécurité, chargé de surveiller le respect de cette obligation juridique en raison des articles 48 et 49 de la Charte, et toute la Commu nauté internationale mettront en œuvre la poursuite pénale des criminels internationaux comme il l'ont fait dans l'affaire de l'Incident aérien de Lockerbie. Si les criminels recherchés ne quittent jamais les États au nom desquels ils ont commis les crimes et qui leur accordent éventuellement refuge, il ne reste plus à espérer que l'opportunité politique ou la pres sion internationale dans un nouveau contexte politique international inci tant les futurs gouvernements démocratiques des États concernés à extrader en fin de compte les criminels recherchés vers le Tribunal. Au-delà de ces aspects techniques, le Tribunal devra faire face à la perte de crédibilité des Nations unies, provenant de leur action ambiguë consistant à juger les politiciens avec lesquels elles « négocient » la paix dans le moment présent. Demain il ne sera pas facile de reprocher à ces « négociateurs » d'aujourd'hui les crimes (tels que les « purifications ethniques » extensives) dont les conséquences ont déjà été entérinées par les traités dits de paix portant sur un partage géographique de la Bosnie- Herzégovine. Lesdits traités sont de fait ressentis plutôt comme un « Diktat » de Genève que comme un traité de paix proprement dit. B. — Nouveau rôle du Conseil de sécurité L'évocation des problèmes politiques concernant l'exercice de la répres sion pénale et les insuffisances de la diplomatie internationale actuelle ne doit pas cependant nous conduire à négliger les chances que fait naître l'établissement d'une justice pénale internationale. Le Tribunal de l'O.N.U. arrive sans doute un peu tard pour avoir une influence dissuasive et pré ventive sur le conflit yougoslave. Toutefois, le Tribunal trouve sa justifi cation dans plusieurs hypothèses. D'une part, il serait déjà un petit succès si l'on demandait des comptes à une dizaine ou à une cinquantaine de personnes sur les centaines ou milliers de personnes responsables de crimes lors de ce conflit. Au surplus, les procès publics de criminels de guerre permettraient de mieux entendre les victimes — qui autrement restent sans défense — dans les reportages internationaux sur la guerre dans les Balkans. D'autre part, l'établissement du Tribunal doit être jugé en vue du contexte global d'une intensification et d'une évolution des activités des Nations unies. A l'heure actuelle, plus de 53.000 casques bleus sont sta tionnés sur quatre continents dans le cadre de treize missions toutes dif férentes (99). Cela montre combien le Conseil de sécurité élargit continuellement et avec un dynamisme nouveau son rôle d'organe suprême de l'ordre international, responsable du maintien et du rétablissement de la paix, toujours par une interprétation téléologique et extensive de ses compétences en vertu du chapitre VII de la Charte. A ceci s'ajoute la croissance remarquable de ses activités législatives dès 1991, mesurée par le nombre des résolutions adoptées (100). Pour le Conseil qui exerce déjà les fonctions d'un pouvoir exécutif international et d'un pouvoir législatif international (même si ce dernier, en particulier, est encore assorti de limites), il semble normal qu'il commence à assurer une fonction nou velle: celle d'un pouvoir judiciaire international. C. — Du Tribunal ad hoc à la Cour criminelle internationale permanente. La justification de l'établissement du Tribunal se trouve dans l'avenir. Le Tribunal apparaît comme la cellule germinale d'une juridiction pénale permanente et quasi universelle, chargée de la répression, dans le monde entier, des violations graves au droit international humanitaire. Une telle Cour criminelle internationale pourrait représenter le « flanc » juridique d'un nouveau concept plus large, plus global, d'interventions humani taires (101); un concept développé par une Organisation des Nations unies

39 en pleine mutation qui ne resterait plus le spectateur impuissant des atteintes graves aux droits de l'Homme mais qui s'immiscerait pour les prévenir et les combattre de plus en plus souvent et de plus en plus tôt. La voie menant à une Cour mondiale est donc ouverte grâce à la mise en place du Tribunal. Cela vaut même si l'institution d'une Cour crimi nelle internationale (C. C. L), fondée sur la ratification des États, n'avait pas lieu. Voici où se situe la véritable valeur intrinsèque du mécanisme du chapitre VII de la Charte : la procédure est si flexible qu'une simple décision du Conseil de sécurité suffira pour déléguer au Tribunal ad hoc, actuellement compétent dans le seul cas du conflit yougoslave, la compé tence juridictionnelle pour tout conflit ultérieur, le cas échéant. Le Tri bunal existant déjà et en état de fonctionnement (une fois une telle résolution adoptée), la menace d'une poursuite-pénale pèsera réellement et d'un jour à l'autre sur les têtes des criminels de guerre agissant dans la région concernée. L'effet dissuasif sera tout à fait différent de ce qui se passe à l'heure actuelle dans le conflit yougoslave (102). Dans cette perspective, l'arsenal juridique mis en place par la Charte des Nations unies, créée à San Francisco il y a plus 49 ans, se révèle aussi complet que flexible. La Charte procure donc au système interna tional une structure assez effective et efficace pour que l'on puisse accepter de relever, sur sa base, le défi d'un âge nouveau qui promet d'être com plexe.
