La création et l'évolution du système antarctique Toute analyse relative au régime juridique de l'Antarctique doit tenir compte des particularités que présente le milieu naturel de cette région. Elles forment non seulement le cadre dans lequel les mesures adoptées doivent être mises en œuvre mais elles exercent en plus une influence déterminante sur leur application. L'Antarctique est une dernière frontière'. Continent vaste comme l'Europe occidentale et les Etats-Unis, elle est presque entièrement recou verte d'une couche de glace dont l'épaisseur moyenne dépasse les deux kilomètres. La rigueur du climat, l'éloignement et l'isolement se sont unis pour y interdire très longtemps la présence humaine. Dans un environne ment aussi .hostile, l'homme reste un intrus: il ne peut y séjourner qu'au bénéfice d'un lourd appui logistique. Les chasseurs de phoques, les balei niers, les explorateurs et enfin les scientifiques se sont succédés dans cette région depuis un peu plus de deux siècles. Malgré l'installation récente d'une cinquantaine de bases scientifiques, l'Antarctique demeure un vaste désert de glace qui ne fait toujours l'objet d'aucune souveraineté territo riale reconnue. Continent témoin, l'Antarctique dissimule l'histoire climatique de la planète dans les nombreuses couches de son manteau de glace. Labora toire unique, elle a attiré l'attention de la communauté scientifique qui en fit l'un des trois secteurs d'étude de l'Année géophysique internationale de 1957 — 58. Pendant dix-huit mois, les chercheurs de douze Etats coopé rèrent activement dans cette région, ayant décidé d'oublier les différends idéologiques ou politiques qui pourraient les opposer 2 . Le succès retentis sant que connut cet événement scientifique sans précédent fut directement à l'origine du Traité sur l'Antarctique, conclu à Washington le 1 er décembre 1959. L'ambassadeur norvégien Edvard HAMBRO reconnaît la dette de la communauté internationale envers les hommes de science en écrivant que: «The Antarctic Treaty is probably the best example in history of politi cians and diplomats being drawn into action by scientists» 3 . Le principal problème qui se posa aux auteurs du Traité de Washing ton était celui de la souveraineté. Durant la première moitié du vingtième siècle, sept Etats, dits «possessionnés», avaient émis des prétentions territo riales sur des secteurs déterminés de l'Antarctique 4 . Ces revendications n'avaient pas été reconnues par les cinq autres Etats qui menaient des activités dans la région 5 . En outre, les prétentions de trois Etats portaient sur des secteurs qui se chevauchaient en tout ou partie. La tentative britannique de porter la controverse devant la Cour internationale de justice se heurta aux refus de l'Argentine et du Chili de reconnaître la compétence du Tribunal et celui-ci raya par conséquent les affaires de son rôle 6 . Pour éviter que cette situation dangereuse n'explose, une solution toute pragmatique fut trouvée: l'article IV «gela» la position que chaque Etat représenté dans la capitale américaine défendait. Cet «accord de ne pas être d'accord» forme la base du régime commun d'administration qui s'est progressivement mis en place sur ce continent 7 . Destiné à perpétuer la coopération fructueuse qui avait uni les scienti fiques pendant l'Année géophysique internationale, le Traité sur l'Antarc tique reconnaît, dans son préambule, qu'«il est de l'intérêt de l'humanité tout entière que l'Antarctique soit à jamais réservée aux seules activités pacifiques et ne devienne ni le théâtre, ni l'enjeu des différends internatio naux». Pour donner effet à cette déclaration d'intention, l'article I pro hibe la militarisation du continent et l'article V y interdit les explosions nucléaires ainsi que l'entreposage des déchets radioactifs. Enfin, les articles II et III posent le principe de la liberté de la recherche scientifique et

44 engagent les Parties contractantes à coopérer en échangeant les résultats de leurs observations scientifiques. Le Traité sur l'Antarctique est muet sur la question des ressources naturelles que l'on trouve sur le continent ou dans les eaux qui l'entourent. Pour éviter qu'elles ne soient prélevées sans discernement, quatre régle mentations ont été élaborées ultérieurement: la Convention de Londres du 1" juin 1972 pour la protection des phoques de l'Antarctique 8 , la Conven tion de Canberra du 20 mai 1980 sur la conservation de la faune et de la flore marines de l'Antarctique 9 , la Convention de Wellington du 2 juin 1988 sur la réglementation des activités relatives aux ressources minérales de l'Antarctique 10 et le Protocole de Madrid au Traité sur l'Antarctique du 4 juin 1991 sur la protection de l'environnement". Ces instruments, ainsi que les quelque 200 recommandations adoptées à l'occasion des réunions périodiques des membres du Traité, forment désormais un ordre juridique complexe qu'un auteur a baptisé «système antarctique» 12 . Conclusion Entré en vigueur il y a plus de trente ans, le Traité sur l'Antarctique a posé les bases d'un régime juridique dynamique ayant connu un succès étonnant. Au bas de la planète, un vaste continent a été démi'.itarisé et tenu à l'écart des engins nucléaires et des déchets radioactifs. Dans ce fabuleux laboratoire, les scientifiques de 41 Etats représentant les princi paux systèmes économiques et politiques du monde coopèrent dans l'inté rêt de l'humanité. Le prélèvement des ressources naturelles paraît désor mais contrôlé et le fragile environnement de cette région a récemment fait l'objet d'une réglementation globale de protection. Ce bilan est unique dans l'histoire des relations internationales. L'une des raisons de cette réussite réside dans l'approche pragmatique suivie par les négociateurs chaque fois qu'ils élaboraient une nouvelle réglementation. La réticence qu'ils ont manifestée à créer de lourdes structures administratives reflète la volonté des Parties consultatives au Traité sur l'Antarctique de proposer des solutions simples et efficaces aux problèmes qui affectent le continent austral. L'expérience s'est chargée de confirmer tout le bien-fondé de cette philosophie. ¥ ¥ ¥ ¥ ¥

KEITH SOMERVILLE Africa entered the 1990s in a mood of hope and expectation. The first three months of the new decade saw the independence of Namibia, the unbanning of the African National Congress (ANC) and the release of Nelson Mandela in South Africa and, across the continent, a growing wave of demands for democratic reform and greater respect for human rights. In the first 18 months of the 1990s, 11 African heads of state fell from power ­ four of them actually voted out of office (in Benin. Cape Verde, São Tomé e Principe and Zambia). In Côte d'Ivoire. Félix Houphouët­Boingy. the doyen of African autocrats, had been forced by a combination of domestic protest and French political pressure to allow the formation of legal opposition parties and to submit himself to a competitive presidential election. The nature of politics in Africa seemed to be changing and changing fast. Close observers of the African scene, including direct participants, spoke of a 'new era for democracy and political reconciliation' or even of the coming of a "second independence' . for Africa. ' Coinciding as it did with the end of the Cold War and the demise of the one­party. Communist regimes of Eastern Europe, the political metamorphosis in Africa was seen as part of the formation of a new world order that would lead to a safer, more democratic and less violent world. Five years on, what does the balance­sheet look like for Africa'? At first glance, it is depressing. It is difficult to avoid the feeling that Africa is heading for total insolvency ­ politically, economi­ cally and in terms of human survival. Hundreds of thousands have been killed in genocidal violence in Rwanda: nearly 2m more Rwandans have become refugees in neighbouring countries; hundreds of thousands have died in two years of renewed civil war in Angola; and Somalia remains in a state of political and social disintegration. On a lesser scale of human suffering. This makes depressing reading. It can be interpreted, if one is so minded, as a failure of African political leaders to grasp the opportunities that presented themselves and as an indication that somehow Africa is politically immature and a permanent eco­ nomic basket­case. With the end of the Cold War and consequent disappearance of superpower conflict from the African political and security equations, there was a belief, now shown to have been over­optimistic and naive, that a major and malign influence had been removed from the continent. This was seen as an opportunity for Africa to make a new start politically and to achieve a greater level of continental, regional, national and human security than if .pis~£/£ Τ r ¡..;_ ι Γ Γ U LL î wJ it had previously enjoyed. This opportunity, according to some Western observers and politicians, has been missed and Africa has descended once more into anarchy. But how accurate is this view of the origin of Africa's political and security problems, of the prospects for change in the 1990s and of the influence of external powers on political developments and security in Africa'? Just α question of time? When the voices calling for democracy in individual African states began to be heard ­ and it should be remembered that the rise of the one­party state had not gone totally unopposed and some proponents of greater democracy kept up the fight against autocracy in the 1970s and 1980s ­ they were heard in Europe and North America as an echo of the popular protests gaining strength in Eastern Europe. Some African leaders, such as President Omar Bongo of Gabon who spoke of the 'east wind shaking the coconut palms', also wrote off the pro­democracy movements as copies of those in Eastern Europe ­ though they had a definite political axe to grind in representing any opposition movements as copycats or foreign imports. But it should be remembered that the protests which took place in Cotonou, Abidjan, Libreville, Lusaka and Dar es Salaam predated or coincided with those in Leipzig, Prague, Sofia and Bucharest. President Mathieu Kérékou's pro­Marxist govern­ ment in Cotonou was being shaken to its foundations by civil service strikes and demonstrations by teachers and students; it was beset by a loss of support in the army and security forces months before the regimes started falling in Eastern Europe. Yet very experienced and knowledgeable Africa­watchers such as the American diplomat, Chester Crocker, still interpreted the pres­ sures on left­wing regimes in Africa largely as a consequence of the fall of Communism in Eastern Europe. But it can be argued that while events in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe had some influence on changing political atti­ tudes in Africa, they were not the spark which ignited the democracy movements, nor were they a major determinant of the course of events in Africa. This argument is crucial to understand­ ing why many Western politicians and some commentators experienced a crisis of expectations when Angola's civil war resumed, when Burundi and Rwanda degenerated into ethnic conflict and authoritarian rule continued elsewhere. The expec­ tations of a new dawn for Africa were based on a misunderstand­ ing of the extent of external political influences on Africa's own political metamorphosis. It cannot be denied that the demise of Communism and authoritarian, one­party rule in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe did affect Africa, but as only one of a number of factors which led to a resurgence in African demands for democracy, accountability of governments, an end to corruption and eco­ nomic mismanagement, and greater respect for freedom of speech

46 and basic human rights. In explaining the origins of Africa's political and economic crises, and thus the roots of the movements for reform, the following key factors have to be taken into account. • The most important is the failure of African governments to fulfil their end of an implicit social pact with their people: African autocrats promised economic progress in exchange for restric tions on the political rights of their citizens. It was evident that economic progress in much of Africa had stalled or had been replaced by economic decline. 2 Single-party rule had been justi fied as necessary for national unity and economic development in multi-ethnic, economically underdeveloped states. After 30 years of authoritarian rule, African states had not benefited economi cally and in many cases had actually suffered stagnation, wide spread corruption and a dramatic decline in welfare and living standards. • Economic reforms necessitated by economic decline or im posed by the International Monetary Fund (IMF), the World Bank or donor nations have led to a decline in the power of the state and have required a greater diffusion of economic power to private individuals. This has provided potential opposition movements with a greater degree of economic independence than during the period when the economic patronage of the state was paramount. • The democratic reforms and uprisings in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union, 'widely reported even in the restricted African media, had a visible impact on the African political elite, as well as amongst the general population'. 3 Although the effects of the popular uprisings in Eastern Europe were not limited to Marxist- inclined states in Africa, the demise of Communism could not but devalue the ideological justifications put forward by the pro- socialist leaders of state such as Angola, Benin, Congo, Ethiopia and Mozambique - though as with the genesis of the popular demonstrations against one-party rule, many of Africa's socialist states had moved their economic and political policies in a more pragmatic direction in the 1980s, before perestroika, as a result of domestic economic and political crises. • A growth in the proportion of young people in the population, particularly urban, educated but unemployed youths. Those bom in the period since independence are less inclined to accept that sacrifices still have to be made to consolidate the gains of independence and are more aware of the relative freedom and higher standards of living enjoyed by their counterparts outside Africa. Many more of them have received secondary education than did the preceding generation, and yet they frequently have no prospect of employment or any means of articulating their politi cal and economic interests. This generational pressure is operat ing across the continent from the poorest countries, such as Malawi, to the more prosperous, like Botswana. In 1991, as Zambia was approaching its first multiparty elections for 18 years, President Kaunda told me that one of the reasons he had agreed to scrap the one-party system had been that nearly 7m people out of a population of 8m had been bom since independence and wanted a greater say in national affairs than their elders, who had known the restrictions of colonial rule and had taken part in the struggle for independence. 4 • Perhaps the most important factor stimulating demands for political reform in African countries was the diffusion effect of reforms in other African countries. 5 This was true particularly in francophone Africa, where the upheavals and reforms in Benin begat similar processes in Mali, Niger, Togo, Cameroon and Côte d'Ivoire (though each of those states had its particular mix of the factors mentioned here which slowed or accelerated change and governed the eventual consequences of change). There was also the very influential role played by South Africa, where the unbanning of the ANC, the release of Mandela and the transition to non-racial democracy all undercut the arguments of those elsewhere in Africa who argued that ethnic, linguistic and religious differences were an obstacle to pluralist politics. • Foreign governments and international institutions also played a role in the political changes taking place in Africa. Although it is incorrect to attribute these changes to the manipulations of external actors, those external forces have often played roles supportive of change. 6 These roles have included the use of economic sanctions, through the suspension of aid, against Kenya and Malawi to put pressure on the authoritarian rulers of those states to submit to domestic demands for change. Looking at these factors, by far the most powerful have been the failure of governments to meet the needs of their populations in terms of welfare, living standards and basic political and civil rights; the growth of an educated, urban, unemployed mass of young people whose interests can only be served by economic and political change; and the impact of political change in neighbour ing states. Western pressure and the influence of Eastern Europe both had an effect - but as catalysts or complementary factors, not as primary causes. It was more a matter of generation, patience running out and the length of time since independence than the immediate effects of the 'east wind'. The crisis of expectations The rapid development of the democracy movement in Africa, the global effects of the end of the Cold War and the sudden willingness to apply political conditions to economic aid to Africa all created the impression that irrevocable change was under way. Those in Western Europe and North America who had control of policy towards Africa appear to have had an arrogant and naive belief in the effects of the Cold War and the power of their countries to influence events in Africa through the simple means of exhortation, diplomatic pressure and the threat of the suspen sion of aid. They did not look closely at the origins of change in Africa or the roots of the political and economic crises affecting individual African countries and so developed the expectation that, by removing the external factors they saw as encouraging dictatorial rule or engendering conflict, and by applying pressure, they could change the very nature of political systems. This has proved to be a vastly inflated expectation of their own influence and of the capacity of African societies to evolve. What has happened in Africa has been governed by African political and economic conditions and not by external influence, which has had only a superficial effect. Even where sanctions have assisted or accelerated domestically generated changes, they have not had a decisive effect. In Kenya, Western pressure was important in pushing President Moi into abandoning the one- party model and legalising opposition parties. But it was unable to exercise a governing influence on the way in which the ruling Kenya African National Union (KANU) party conducted the transition to multiparty politics and fought the subsequent elec tions. The nature of the transition period and the result of the elections were governed rather by the ability of KANU to use the state machinery for its own political purposes, the divided nature of the opposition, and the persistence of a 'winner-takes-all' approach to politics. This latter factor has been demonstrated, too, in Zambia, Côte d'Ivoire, and other states across Africa.

47 The expectation that the mere creation of a multiplicity of parties would bring popular participation and government ac­ countability has been frustrated by a belief that winning an election is the sole purpose of political parties and is an end in itself rather than the means to a broader end ­ that of implementing policies aimed at achieving political stability and economic development. The winning parties ­ including those established to fight for political reform ­ have all too frequently acted as their single­party predecessors did. The concept of a functioning opposition with a right to question the policies and actions of government and to criticise constructively has not developed in most states. Alongside the failure of parties and politicians to move away from the 'winner­takes­all' model of politics, there is in many African states the absence of the organised interest groups which make up 'civil society' in more participatory polities ­ that range of organised interests outside the state which are generally present in advanced industrial societies and can contain the excesses of state power, or at least channel and express popular interests. 7 Such groups were often destroyed or weakened by the repressive policies of authoritarian governments or became transformed into political parties in the transition to democracy and so lost the ability to articulate non­partisan concerns. But where such groups have developed and remained influential, as in Botswana and Zimbabwe, there has been greater success in making governments accountable or limiting their arbitrary actions. The crisis of expectations arose within Africa from the belief that change in itself would be automatically positive and that the very existence of a plurality of parties would mean more account­ able and efficient government. Outside Africa, the crisis devel­ oped as a result of the over­emphasis on the influence of super­ power conflict in Africa and on the power of Western states to guide the process of change with minimal involvement. A final point, but a crucial one, is that a primary factor in ending the acquiescence of African populations has been the failure of living standards to improve. The democratically elected governments in Africa have no more chance of healing their chronically sick economies than did many of their predecessors. The level of accountability of a government may lead to a reduction in corruption but will not necessarily mean an increase in efficiency ­ in fact, greater accountability will lead to greater inflationary pressures (because of the demand for higher wages, better provision of health and education and assured supplies of staple commodities); increased industrial unrest (as the lifting of repressive legislation allows for freer trades­union activity); and an increased likelihood that governments will be required by their supporters (and electors) to resist the conditionality put on aid by international financial institutions and donors. Structural adjust­ ment programmes in Africa have hardly been an unqualified success and have frequently had the effect of increasing poverty and creating unemployment. Such consequences would make it impossible for governments which have to submit to regular tests of popular support through elections to sustain economic austerity programmes and restructuring in order to meet the demands of external organisations or states. In terms of future policies to assist Africa, Western govern­ ments should go back to basics. They need to gain an understand­ ing of the domestic political social and economic roots of the crisis ofthe state and of the individual in Africa. It was a mistake to believe that the much­vaunted but all too often illusory global ■peace dividend' would mean that the political and security environment in Africa would change. There have been major advances in some countries, notably in southern Africa (Angola excepted). It is to be hoped that even in some of those (Côte d'Ivoire and Kenya, for example), where authoritarianism has remained despite the advent of legal opposition parties, the campaigns for greater democracy have begun to create a culture in which existing civic groups, such as churches, legal associa­ tions or human­rights monitoring groups, will be able to maintain or even widen their roles to support the principle of government accountability. It is the growth of civic society that will provide the real foundation for greater democracy in a way that the existence of a multiplicity of parties has not. In economic tenns, the use of aid to coerce governments into superficial reforms has not been matched by a willingness to assist actively those states which are moving in the right direction. The debt burden on African states is an insurmountable obstacle for those attempting to reform and reconstruct their economies; it prevents meaningful economic development or the economic empowerment of communities and individuals and serves to maintain low welfare provision and widespread poverty. The development of ci vie society and democracy in Africa requires not only political will but the right economic conditions. At the end of 1993, 20 African states had debts in excess of the total gnp, a further 20 had debts equal to between 50 and 100 percent of gnp. The debt burden imposes heavy annual interest and capital repayments, depriving governments of development and working capital. In the wake of the fall of Communism in Eastern Europe, countries like Poland gained massively from debt write­offs. It had 50 per cent of its debt written off by the West ­ 'in contrast to the West's unwillingness to do anything comparable for Africa'. 8 If the West should look again at its economic policies towards Africa, then African political leaders have to look at the whole future of the state in Africa and at the constitutional frameworks within which states operate. Eritrea successfully seceded from Ethiopia ­ there may be cases in which secession, regional autonomy or federalism are the solutions to regional and ethnic conflict. The solution to the three­decades­old problem of the 'winner­takes­all' approach is harder to identify, though the early experience of power­sharing in South Africa suggests that at least during periods of transition from authoritarianism, civil war or military rule, power­sharing offers a way of overcoming major political differences and of forming a workable government which can then oversee the construction of a more lasting constitutional framework. DESPITE pre-election predictions of violent disruption, the country's first democratic general election took place in an atmosphere of reconciliation and hope for a future in which past injustice would be rectified and the 'new South Africa' welcomed back into the international community. For a brief moment — and, of course, it might not last as the inevitable constraints imposed by scarce resources, rising expectations and external pressures complicate decision making — South Africa appeared to have taken a major step towards Nelson Mandela's goal of a 'nation united in diversity'. 1 Certainly, one striking feature of the four-year transition was the willingness of the elites engaged in the negotiating process to accommodate each other as they sought to reach agreement on a new constitution in a spirit of 'consensus and compromise'. And the same spirit is meant to inspire the day- to-day working of the Government of National Unity and Reconstruction (GNU) which, in effect, is a grand coalition of all the major talents. The outcome of the election in terms of votes cast and seats won was much as expected. Nineteen political parties competed for four hundred seats in the National Assembly and altogether some 19,276,000 votes were cast (the total electorate was estimated to be 22 million). The result was 62.65 per cent for the African National Congress (ANC) (252 seats); the Afrikaner National Party (NP) won 20.39 per cent of the vote (82 seats); and Cilici Mangosutho Buthelezi's Inkatha Freedom Party (IFP) gained 10.54 per cent (43 seats). Thus the ANC has a substantial majority in the National Assembly and also has effective control of seven of the nine provincial assemblies together with an overwhelming majority in the 90-member Senate (ten members chosen from each province). The NP captured the Western Cape region and the IFP took office in Natal-Kwazulu with a slender majority over its ANC rival. The remaining 16 parties fared badly: some were obliterated; others such as the Democrat Parly (DP) — 1.7 per cent of votes and seven seats; the Pan-Africanisi Congress (PAC) 2.25 per cent and six seats; and the white righi - wing Freedom Front (FF) 1.7 per cent of the vote and nine seats — constitute a tiny opposition to the coalition government. Given their differing ideological perspectives it will be difficult for the parties to cooperate over the long term.

49 FOREIGN POLICY ASPIRATIONS The foreign policy of the new government is still at a formative stage. There has — over the last four years — been considerable debate about the role South Africa might play in the international community. There has also been discussion about how to change the ethos of the Department of Foreign Affairs and this will intensify as new, young black entrants — many of whom have been trained abroad — enter the service. There is, too, a dawning recognition that — following the demise of apartheid and the harsh visibility the apartheid state endured for nearly four decades — South Africa will in time become 'just another country' scrambling for trade and investment in a world which is highly competitive. On the other hand, the new government aspires to a foreign policy which is driven by more than orthodox economic imperatives. There is an understandable desire to play a role in the southern African region, to help promote a degree of cooperation in areas like transport, power and communications to name but three — perhaps ultimately leading to a functionally integrated region. In this way southern Africa might well avoid the marginalizätion which threatens much of the test of Africa in the decades ahead. But progress is likely to be slow unless and until institutional structures are created which cater for the diverse interests of all the parties concerned. Yet another obstacle in the path of this objective is the fear of South Africa's smaller neighbours, the governments of which have unhappy memories of South Africa's hegemonic ambitions and policies in the era of apartheid. The new government is well aware of these fears and President Mandela has stressed the need for 'sensitivity and restraint' in the formulation and conduct of regional policy. Furthermore, a guiding assumption of the new government is — given a stable polity and economic revival — that South Africa might well become an 'engine of growth' for the region, with readily available investment and technical assistance and increased trade benefiting all. But this objective — at the very least — assumes an end to the civil wars that have plagued Angola and Mozambique for twenty years; it also assumes that cooperation will be possible on such sensitive issues as migration, for example. In particular, the movement of workers — both unskilled and professional — to South Africa in search of better wages and conditions will be an obvious source of conflict. After all, the South African government is committed to job creation for its own unemployed — some 47 per cent in the formal economy — and will, therefore, resist an influx of workers from abroad. At the same time regional governments will resent the emigration of scarce and skilled professionals to South Africa. There may also be conflicts of interest between competing trade agreements. Reconciliation will be needed between the objectives of the Preferential Trade Area (PTA) in southern and eastern Africa, from which South Africa is currendy excluded, and the South African Customs Union (SACU) which provides for free trade between South Africa, Lesotho, Botswana, Swaziland and Namibia.

50 The cultivation of a wider continental role is also a key ambition of the new government. President Mandela has already come under pressure to play a mediating role in the conflicts that bedevil Africa: Angola, Mozambique, Rwanda, etc. Yet he is conscious of the danger that his country's diplomatic resources and indeed his own skills might well be overstretched by trying to do too much. The means by which he (in association with F. W. de Klerk) transformed the South African domestic political scene are not necessarily appropriate for setting civil conflicts elsewhere. These have a peculiar dynamism of their own and are only likely to be promising areas for mediation if and when the parties involved conclude that the benefits to be derived from continuing the conflict are outweighed by the advantages of seeking external assistance in their resolution. At that stage — and only then — will South Africa's diplomatic efforts become relevant. There will, no doubt, be attempts to involve a newly constituted South African National Defence Force (SANDF) in peace-keeping operations. How the new government will respond is difficult to say at this stage. Yet however tempting the prospect may be, South Africa will face precisely the same constraints against intervention — especially with respect to questions of peace enforcement — in areas wracked by civil war, that have been characteristic of states elsewhere. Finally in this context, South Africa will attempt to enhance its economic links with its traditional trading partners in the West and with Japan. In 1990, for example, the EC accounted for 27.3 per cent of South African exports while the USA (4 per cent), Japan (6.4 per cent) and Africa (6.7 per cent) were the next most important customers. Similarly, the EC (44.7 per cent), the USA (11.4 per cent), Japan (9.8 per cent) and Africa (1.6 per cent) supplied the bulk of South Africa's imports. 9 South Africa's potential economic attraction for Western states will inevitably depend on external perceptions of the new government's economic policies and its commitment to ensuring free market theory and practice. It will also depend on how far it succeeds in projecting itself as a stable polity in which the level of violence has been significantly reduced and the security and profitability of investment secured. * * * * *

53 Eine Umgestaltung der Binnenwirtschaft wird aber nur durch Eingriffe in den in China unangetasteten Staats- und Parteiapparat möglich. Das agrarisch ge prägte China konnte darauf verzichten, weil es schon zu Beginn seines Reformprozesses eine produktive Landwirtschaft und gesicherte Versorgungsbasis be saß. In Kuba muß diese Grundlage erst als Vorausset zung für jede weitere Entwicklung geschaffen werden. Die Landwirtschaft und der Zuckeranbau wurden aber bis jetzt von der zentralisierten Verwaltung kontrol liert. Liberalisierungen setzen also politische Reformen voraus. Die bisher vorhandene punktuelle Übereinstim mung zwischen großen Teilen der Bevölkerung und ih rer Führung ist dabei die entscheidende Komponente einer Zukunftsperspektive. Erinnern wir uns: Der Ver such der UdSSR, notwendige Strukturreformen der Gesamtwirtschaft und der mit ihr unteilbar verknüpf ten zentralen Staatsverwaltung durch eine radikale Re form zu bewältigen, verursachte durch den Abbau der materiellen Basis eine massive Verschlechterung des Lebensstandards. Die daraus folgenden sozialen und politischen Implikationen brachten dieses Vorhaben schließlich zum Scheitern. In Kuba führte eine noch schärfere Verschlechterung der wirtschaftlichen Lage und der Versorgungssituation nicht in dem gleichen Maße zur Legitimationskrise des Systems und deutet so auf eine breite soziale und politische Akzeptanz der Durchführung dieser radikalen Reformen hin. Damit hat die kubanische Regierung die Gelegenheit, die in anderen realsozialistischen Ländern gescheiterten Re- formierungsversuche unter politisch günstigeren Be dingungen zu wagen und das Paradigma der begrenzten Transformationsfähigkeit des realsozialistischen Sy stems erneut zur Diskussion zu stellen. Daß die Regierung noch über eine Legitimation ver fügt, haben zuletzt die Wahlen zur Nationalversamm lung im Februar 1993 gezeigt. Über 90 vH der Bevölke rung votierten für die Regierungspolitik. Die Wahlmo dalitäten entsprachen trotz vielfältig kritisierter Punk te denen eines Plebiszits 35 ). Diese offensichtliche hohe Legitimation ist einer der Gründe, weswegen das „so zialistische Projekt" Kubas den Zusammenbruch der meisten realsozialistischen Länder überlebte. Die bisherige Regierungspolitik hat über die sich for mierenden Differenzierungsprozesse durch den Schwarzmarkt und die Dollarlegalisierung zu einem Abschmelzen dieses gesellschaftlichen Konsens ge führt. Die Gräben zwischen den verschiedenen sozia len Gruppen Kubas sind tiefer geworden. Die sozialen Unruhen im August, aber auch die ihr folgenden Loya litätskundgebungen, die mehr als eine halbe Million Menschen mobilisierten, sind Ausdruck dieser Polari sierung. Was sich bis jetzt durch anschwellende Flücht lingsströme oder als impulsiver Ausbruch von Ver zweiflung und Unmut kund tat, kann zu politischen Forderungen werden, wenn nicht bald eine Verbesse rung der Lebensbedingungen erreicht wird. Die bisher zentral dirigierte Ausweitung von ökono mischen Präferenzsektoren (z. B. Tourismus) ist als Strategie der Intensivierung extensiver Produktion und Reproduktion schon früher im realen Sozialismus der UdSSR und Osteuropas gescheitert. Eine integrative Wirtschaftsstrategie kann jetzt nur noch durch eine ho rizontale Vernetzung der Wirtschaftssubjekte erfolg reich sein. Das bedeutet eine Entkoppelung der politi schen Entscheidungsstrukturen von der ökonomischen Verfügungsgewalt und eine gleichzeitige Demokratisie rung und Dezentralisierung beider Sphären. Die Revolution hat hier nur zaghafte Schritte gewagt: Die Reform der Wahlgesetzgebung 1992 räumte durch basisdemokratische Elemente den Gemeinden größere politische Autonomie ein. Aber erst die Ausweitung dieses Prinzips auf die übergeordneten Entscheidungs ebenen der Provinzparlamente und der Nationalver sammlung würde es gewährleisten, in der zentralisier ten Wirtschaft eine größere Produktionsautonomie einzuführen. International kaum beachtet, leitete es einen Dezentra- lisierungs- und Rationalisierungsprozeß der Zentral verwaltung ein, der innerhalb eines Jahres abgeschlos sen sein soll. Ziel ist es, den Staatsapparat in vielen Be reichen zu straffen und flexiblere Entscheidungsstruk turen zu schaffen. Der kubanische Staatsapparat befindet sich jetzt in dem existentiellen Konflikt, selbst seine Funktion radi kal verändern zu müssen, um die nötigen Transforma tionen zu ermöglichen: Einerseits muß er seinen Machteinfluß beschneiden, um den Wirtschaftseinhei ten mehr Autonomie gewähren zu können. Anderer seits muß er Machteinfluß wahren, um die Transfor mation zu steuern und die sozialen Komponenten zu sichern 37 ). Gelingt ihm dieser Balanceakt, werden in der Bin nenwirtschaft bald weitere Deregulierungen folgen. Die ökonomische Homogenität kann nur durch eine Transformation des Binnensektors erreicht werden, die zu einer dynamischen Erhöhung des Produktivi tets- und realen Einkommensniveaus führt und damit den Staatshaushalt entlastet. Der rasche Aufbau einer produktiven Landwirt schaft hat dabei eine Schlüsselposition. Die anfänglichen disproportionalen Ein kommenszuwächse können Impulse aussenden, die ne ben dem Abbau der Arbeitslosigkeit neue Produktions bereiche stimulieren. Dem

Die Kollektivierung war ein erster Schritt, er­ hält aber nur Effizienz, wenn sich der Staat auch aus Vermarktung und Preisbildung zurückzieht. Die Institutionalisierung eines wirtschaftspoliti­ schen Instrumentariums durch eine Banken­, Steuer­ und Preisreform und die Einführung von regulierten Märkten muß den seit diesem Jahr angestrebten Ein­ satz von Geld­ und Fiskalpolitik folgen. Nach einer Überwindung der Versorgungskrise liegt Kubas größte Perspektive in einer Reintegration in den karibischen Raum, die seit Jahren von der Regierung mit einer diplomatischen Offensive vorangetrieben wird. Die 1975 eingeleitete Industrialisierung konzen­ trierte sich auf einen für den Realsozialismus typischen Aufbau der Schwerindustrie. Die Insel kann deshalb heute auf Industriekapazitäten zurückgreifen, die sonst nirgends in der Region vorhanden sind: Kuba verfügt als einziges Land der Karibik über Zementfabriken, die bei voller Auslastung den Bedarf der gesamten Region decken würden. Dazu kommt eine der größten Ölraffi­ nerien der Zone, die für die rohölfördernden Länder wie Mexiko, Venezuela und Kolumbien zur Verfügung stehen könnte. Kleineren Fabriken der Textil­, Elektro­ und Elektronikbranche, die häufig erst in der zweiten Hälfte der 80er Jahre in Betrieb gingen und wettbe­ werbsfähig sind, fehlt es heute primär an Inputs zur Auslastung oder Expansion ihrer Kapazitäten. Für die Papierfabriken der Insel wurde eine neue Technologie entwickelt, mit der aus einem Abfallprodukt der Zuk­ kerproduktion, der Zuckerrohrbagasse, Papier herge­ stellt werden kann 38 ). Dieses Beispiel verweist auf ein weiteres Potential, auf die hochqualifizierten Arbeitskräfteressourcen der Insel: In mehr als 10 Wissenschaftpools fördert die Re­ gierung die Entwicklung von ausgewählten Technolo­ gien in einer bedürfnisorientierten Produktionsform für unterentwickelte Regionen. Den Wissenschaftlern Kubas ist es gelungen, wettbewerbsfähige Produktpa­ letten in der Pharmaindustrie sowie der Gen­ und Computertechnologie herzustellen. Die Förderung von innovativer Technologie und Forschung bietet der In­ sel die entwicklungspolitische Perspektive, durch eine Integration in einen der dynamischsten Wirtschaftsbe­ reiche der Zukunft die Abhängigkeit von Rohstoffprei­ sen zu überwinden. Während die dazu notwendigen Standards erreicht sind und sich bilaterale Kooperatio­ nen ausweiten, erschweren zur Zeit noch die Begren­ zungen der Vermarktung die weltweite Nutzung dieser Devisenquellen 39 ). Das kubanische Humankapital kann gleichzeitig zum Aufbau anderer Entwicklungssektoren eingesetzt werden. Schon heute wird versucht, die Standards der Technik (vor allem der weitentwickelten Zuckerindu­ strie) und des Bildungs­ und Gesundheitswesens als Dienstleistung anzubieten. Sollte eine Integration in die Region Kubas Position aufwerten, und die Insel kann als einer der größten Binnenmärkte der Karibik ein attraktiver Handelspartner werden, würde der nö­ tige Aufbau einer adäquaten Infrastruktur durch die vorhandenen Bildungsreserven zusätzlich begünstigt. Kuba besitzt schon heute ein ausgebautes Straßennetz und ein Kommunikationssystem, das zur Zeit mit spa­ nischer Unterstützung modernisiert wird. Die kubanische Transformation besitzt also neben ihren traditionellen Produktionsstrukturen verschie­ dene Entwicklungspotentiale. Ihre Nutzung wird da­ von abhängen, ob es nach einer ökonomischen Stabili­ ■ sierung gelingt, die notwendigen Ressourcen zur Mobi­ lisierung einzelnen Sektoren zu erschließen, bzw. durch eine Allokation gleichgewichtig einzusetzen. Ob ein reformiertes Kuba weiter sozialistisch ge­ nannt wird, können die spitzen Zungen der Kubaner am besten entscheiden. Nach dem Zusammenbruch des realen Sozialismus bieten sich zur Zeit für einen ökonomisch rationalen Sozialismus zweifellos nur noch keynesianische Steuerungsinstrumente an 40 ). Sollte es dieser Konzeption aber gelingen, ökonomi­ sche Effizienz mit Sozialstaatlichkeit, kollektive Eigen­ tumsverhältnisse mit partizipativer Mitbestimmung zu verknüpfen, ist sie auf jeden Fall antikapitalistisch, weil sie wesentlichen Strukturelementen des unterent­ wickelten Kapitalismus widerspricht. Gleichzeitig würde sie der Umsetzung der Entwicklungsstrategie der 70er Jahre, der Grundbedürfhisbefriedigung 41 ), neue Bedeutung verschaffen. Kuba könnte so auch in Zukunft ein Entwicklungsmodell für die Länder der so­ genannten „Dritten Welt" bleiben, das beweist, daß eine gerechte Verteilungspolitik und eine ausgebaute Infrastruktur in der Gesundheitsversorgung und Bil­ dung Voraussetzungen sind, um die Bedingungen öko­ nomischer Entwicklung zu erfüllen. Gelingt dieser Reformschritt nicht, wird sich die Krise zwangsläufig weiter verschärfen und den Zusam­ menbruch der egalitären Grundversorgung hervorru­ fen. Folgen wären eine Radikalisierung der begonne­ nen Polarisierung und ein Verteilungskampf aller ge­ sellschaftlichen Interessengruppen um die noch ver­ bliebenen knappen Ressourcen unter dem Einfluß der Vereinigten Staaten und der exilkubanischen Gemein­ schaft. Die Aufgabe des „sozialistischen Prinzips" würde zur Legitimationskrise des Staates und könnte zum ge­ waltsamen Zusammenbruch des Systems führen. Die letzte Chance Kubas, eine Transformation unter Be­ rücksichtigung und mit Beteiligung aller gesellschaft­ lichen Gruppen umzusetzen, wäre vertan und nicht nur die sogenannte „Dritte Welt" um eine Hoffnung ärmer. * * * ¥ ¥

La dynamique régionale en Asie-Pacifique, tant sur le plan économique que sur celui du débat sur les questions de sécurité, a cela d'original qu'elle n'est pas tirée par les «grandes puissances» : les grandes puissances, à l'éche lon mondial (États-Unis) ou à l'échelon régional (Chine), ne sont pas les moteurs de la constitution d'une «région Asie-Pacifique». Il constitue un modèle évolutif, avec une infrastructure institutionnelle qui autorise l'expansion continue des échanges sur des sujets d'intérêt commun 44 . Le gage de son succès est l'attraction qu'il exerce sur les États asiatiques puisque l'Inde et la Mongolie ont exprimé le souhait d'y être intégrées. L'évolution des relations internationales dans la région Asie-Pacifique met en valeur l'importance de l'attrait politique de l'appartenance à une organisation dont le succès économique est plus dû aux États individuels qu'à leur aggregation. Cette évolution apparaît comme une caractéristique de l'après-guerre froide où chaque État reçoit de l'ensemble international régio nal en fonction de ses ressources propres et non simplement parce qu'il est membre de cet ensemble. * * * **

66 Journal of Consumer Policy Volumel7 No. 3 September 1994 Mizanur Rahman Consumer Protection in Bangladesh: «, Q ns Law and Practice Pf '^ J "? 6 2 Any inquiry into the problem of consumer protection in one of the least developed countries, such as Bangladesh, should begin with the existing fundamental differences between consumer protection philoso phies in the developed and developing countries of the world. While a consumer in a developed economy is literally submerged in an ocean of alternative choices, his counterpart in a developing economy suffers from an acute lack of purchasing power. In the latter case, the question is not what to buy, but how to buy. Hence, from a third world point of view, the most important consumer right is the right to be able to satisfy basic needs, a right which according to a recommendation of the IOCU 1985 Bangkok Conference should be added to the UN Guidelines for Consumer Protection. The remaining consumer rights, now internationally recog nised, are the right to safety, the right to be informed, the right to complain, the right to representation, the right to choose and get things at fair price, the right to get compensation, the right to consumer education, and the right to a healthy environment. Needless to say, in Bangladesh where "poverty for the great majority of the people is a grim struggle for survival" (Jansen, 1978, p. 14), consumer rights have little, if any, practical meaning for ordinary people. Nor could the government of this tiny nation-state attach due importance to consumer protection. Bangladesh emerged as an independent state on December 16,1971 following the war of independence which began on March 25 of the same year. After partition of India by the British Raj in 1947, Bangladesh, then known as East Pakistan, constituted the eastern province of Pakistan. It was a part of the State of Pakistan for almost 24 years before finally seceding in 1971 to become an independent and sovereign state known as the People's Republic of Bangladesh. Unfortunately, with the exception of only a few years, the history of Bangladesh was never characterised by political stability and democracy. In the absence of democracy and in times where human rights violations were rampant, consumer protection was but a far cry. Nevertheless, the legal foundation for consumer protection was laid in the initial' years of the republic by the Constitution of Bangladesh, 1972. THE SETTING OF THE BANGLADESH CONSUMER MOVEMENT The consumer movement in Bangladesh is, to put it plainly, still in its nascent stage. Consumer vigilance comes with literacy and knowledge. Only 29.2 percent of the country's total population is literate. As stated by Hasan (1992, p. 25), the introduction of a

67 consumer movement is a complicated social step in our present situation. Unlimited desire for profiteering together with lack of control causes unbearable sufferings for the consumers and particu larly for the people of limited income as they cannot adjust themselves to the great and sudden changes in price level. At present with price rises, adulterated and counterfeit articles of essential goods flooding the market, the lack of protest and agitation from the innocent and silent consumers are making the situation all the more difficult. The vast population is moving in the vicious circle of poverty, illiteracy, and fatalism. It blames its luck and accepts sub-human life as natural, Hasan adds. Under the existing socio-economic and political circumstances, the attention of the government has been shifted to more urgent matters and notwithstanding the decision of the 1990 Bangkok Conference for the countries of Asia and the Pacific to adopt by 1995 consumer protection measures in accordance with the UN Guidelines, no prac tical step has yet been taken in Bangladesh. * a CONCLUSION The foregoing success stories should not lead one to the belief that consumer protection in Bangladesh is adequate. Even though indi vidual successful attempts have played a positive role in arousing awareness among ordinary consumers as regards their rights, the state of consumer protection legislation and practice is still pitiable. The reasons are manifold, but the following are especially promi nent. Firstly, the absence of a proper consumer protection legislation has worsened the position of consumers. The few legislative acts that affect consumer interests are scattered and difficult to find. This also makes the consumer education programme a formidable one. Secondly, filing a complaint for the breach of consumer rights according to the provisions in the aforementioned laws is cumbersome which is detrimental to consumer interests. Most, if not all, of these laws do not empower an ordinary consumer to initiate legal action against the wrong-doer. Rather, it is provided in the laws that only competent government officials are entitled to institute a case against a person accused of violations of "consumer laws." For example, the Drugs (Control) Ordinance, 1982 provides that only the Drug Authority may institute legal proceedings against persons/firms accused of violation of the Ordinance (Pereira & Mahmud, 1993). Thirdly, even in those rare cases when a consumer decides to bring a violation of his legal rights to the notice of the competent govern ment authority, he is likely to find that the concerned official is almost "unapproachable." Very soon the consumer is sure to feel discour aged by the bureaucratic hassle and will try to forget the whole affair. Fourthly, in an environment of unfair market forces, influential government officials are more often "managed" by business interest groups than affected by the moral persuasion of individual consumers or their associations. Sometimes, consumer conflicts with big busi nesses are viewed by interested quarters as the "fate-awarded opportunity" to enrich their material conditions. On some occasions, threats of physical coercion and intimidation are exerted to refrain consumers or their pressure groups from taking any serious step that might adversely affect business interests.

68 Last, but certainly not least, the human zest is missing. In other words, there is no political commitment and programme as regards the protection of consumers. Political parties are found to be dependent on businessmen and industrialists for funds, patronage, etc., and when in power seem to be very unwilling to make any unfriendly gesture against their "friends in need." Nevertheless, the fact that many important laws were adopted after Bangladesh attained independence gives a ray of hope. Successive governments have taken a more positive attitude towards consumer protection. Coupled with mass consumer awareness, the government's good intentions may be the real key to future successful implemen tation of better consumer protection practices in Bangladesh. ABSTRACT. In the least developed third world countries, the most important consumer right is the right to satisfy basic needs. In this paper, the author describes the legal foundations for consumer protection in Bangladesh, foundations which attach the highest importance to the nutritional state of the people and to measures for protection of consumers from products, processes, and services which are hazardous to their health. Some of the laws are pre-1971, the year of independence of Bangladesh; others have been promulgated in more recent years, though not all of the latter have yet been fully implemented. The author also describes the history of the consumer movement in the country, and in particular the work carried out by the Consumers' Association of Bangladesh. The difficulties that consumer organizations meet in a country such as Bangladesh are multifold. Some of the most formidable problems have to do with the fact that legislation is scattered, that consumers themselves cannot initiate legal action against wrong-doers, and that public officials as well as political leaders are often "unapproachable" or more interested in caring for the interests of business. 76 Avant-propos L'annonce, à la fin du mois d'août 1993, que des négociations secrètes entamées au début de l'année en Norvège avaient permis d'aboutir à la rédaction d'une déclaration de principes commune entre Israël et l'OLP frappa le monde de stupeur. Certes, l'obstination du secrétaire d'Etat américain, James Baker, avait déjà permis l'ouverture à Madrid d'une conférence pour la paix, qui, pour la première fois, avait mis face à face l'ensemble des délégations arabes et l'Etat hébreu; le processus ainsi lancé avait débouché sur la constitution de cinq groupes de travail spécialisés sur des questions multilatérales (réfugiés, environnement, contrôle des armements, eau, coopération économique) et sur le démarrage de négociations bilatérales entre Israël et la Syrie, le Liban, la Jordanie et une délégation palestinienne. Mais les mécanismes de négociation mis en place tournèrent rapidement à vide : les dix sessions bilatérales n'aboutirent qu'à des résultats fort modestes et semblaient conduire tout droit à une impasse. Tout progrès significatif se heurtait en effet au refus d'Israël de traiter officiellement avec l'OLP, considérée comme une organisation terroriste. Or, ce veto était inacceptable tant pour les représentants palestiniens que pour les Etats arabes voisins, qui considéraient la levée de l'hypothèque palestinienne comme un préalable à leur propre engagement actif dans les négociations. La constitution du gouvernement Rabin, en juillet 1992, ouvrit la voie à un progrès substantiel des négociations qui aboutit au coup de tonnerre diplomatique de l'été 1993 et facilita le déblocage de l'ensemble du contentieux israélo-arabe. Il faut toutefois noter que la conclusion de cet accord historique n'était pas fortuite : elle s'inscrivait en effet dans la continuité d'une double évolution de l'OLP et d'Israël, tous deux gagnés par un pragmatisme grandissant. Ce changement d'attitude fut incontestablement accéléré par la fin de la bipolarité soviéto-américaine qui avait entretenu, voire envenimé, le conflit régional au Moyen- Orient. Aujourd'hui, cette «paix des braves», à laquelle le président de l'OLP fait souvent allusion, est sur les rails. Certes, il serait exagéré de dire qu'elle l'est définitivement : les négociations sont délicates, les accrocs sérieux, les arrière-pensées nombreuses. Pourtant, ni le massacre de vingt-neuf fidèles musulmans à Hebron, ni les sanglants attentats anti-israéliens de Hamas (39 morts) n'ont donné un coup d'arrêt définitif au processus. Rather, it will pose a more complex and potentially longer and more troublesome challenge to a number of states, from Saudi Arabia on the Persian Gulf to Morocco on the Atlantic - with a rippling impact worldwide. At its core, the Arab-Israeli conflict centred on security issues after the geographic reconfiguration of a strategic region in 1948 - specifically, the redrawing of borders to add the Jewish state of Israel to the Arab-domi nated Middle East. While the initial motives of the Arab belligerents and Israel were existential, the essence of the conflict over the past half a century has turned on competing territorial claims and rival ideologies. At the heart of the Arab-Israeli conflict has been the need to find a modus vivendi for eventual co-existence. In stark contrast, the next phase of Middle East upheaval will centre on a more fundamental - but also more explosive - challenge. Instead of countries fighting against each other, conflict will mainly occur within countries, often pitting societies against their governments. And while it may also" take diverse and disparate forms over the next decade or more, these new conflicts will often be dominated by the same issue: economic, social and political empowerment. For half a century, Arab governments have hidden behind the Arab- Israeli conflict. Now that it is over in the minds of most contestants, regimes of both right and left must confront - and respond to - growing demands for political reformation. Perpetuating the status quo will be a temptation; outside powers and allies may even urge it. But the pressures on regimes already prevent the status quo being a viable long-term solution in virtually every case. Therefore, as the Arab-Israeli dispute is gradually removed from the centre of regional developments in the years ahead, political players and parties in more than 20 Arab states will, either by choice or by force, have to deal with the imperatives of change. The question is not whether to reform, but how to reform. Yet the simplicity of the question is deceptive. Indeed, just as much of the world in the 1990s is somewhat nostalgic about the simplicity of the Cold War era, so the looming challenge to current govern ments and systems in the Middle East may come to make policy-makers nostalgic about the straightforwardness of the Arab-Israeli conflict. 79 Conclusions: Implications for the Outside World The post-peace era is also potentially important to interested parties outside the region - from oil consumers in Asia, Europe and the Americas to neighbouring countries that fear the social and political fall-out from change. Outside parties face difficult choices in the Middle East. The first is between the brittle, authoritarian status quo and the dynamic, but often volatile, stability of political reform. The second, which will play out over time, is over these parties' own role in the post-peace era. First, the temptation of Western leaders willoften be to opt for the status quo. During the Cold War, many Western capitals supported democracy in theory, but effectively turned a blind eye to Middle East dictatorships in the interests of regional stability and their own influence. In the post-peace era, autocratic regimes may again try to stave off pressures for political change by painting the opposition as radical, anti-Western and irrational or by threatening to block Western access to their resources. But external powers, even the United States, cannot save Arab rulers that are under siege because of their own misrule. More fundamentally, as one scholar has put it, the flavour of the 1990s is participation. 20 As the demand for political participation rises, so continued neglect of or indifference to the need for change will undermine, not buttress, Western interest in the Arab world. The protection of fundamental human rights will not alone solve the problems of economic deprivation, unemployment or social grievances. But unless human rights are taken seriously, there is little hope that meaning will be restored to the concept of citizenship in the Arab world. Western policy-makers must thus stand squarely behind the politics of inclusion rather than exclusion. That does not mean that they should summarily abandon allies, but they should not hesitate to counsel regional leaders about the costs to all over the long term if they fail to reform. To be on the right side of history and political reform in the Middle East, the West may occasionally have to confront even some of its key allies. Opposition forces intent on playing within the rules of peaceful reform must not be summarily disqualified from the process, whether inspired by Islamist or secular ideologies. The cost of exclusion is the radicalisation of the opposition, as the Algerian tragedy illustrates. 21 The outside world will also have to be realistic about the pace of reform. Authoritarian governments are unlikely to be transformed quickly into thriving democracies. While the United States and its allies should push for deliberate change and rebuff efforts to stall, they should also be mindful of the abilities of societies to absorb change. Purposeful evolution is always preferable to revolution. Second, after dominating the diplomatic stage in the Middle East for more than a decade, the United States should begin more actively to co-opt allies in the post-peace era. Besides reforms in individual countries, the Middle East as a region faces a daunting array of problems - centred on human development, resource allocation and quality of life. Unless serious steps are taken to improve the daily life of the people of the region, there will be little support for political and economic reform. In confronting this challenge, collective action is required.
